All those letters never sent.He had selected only a small percentage of Diane’s writings and already the courtroom was saturated with her words.Succinctly, dispassionately, Hugi had told the jury what he needed to prove to them in the weeks ahead. His words, transcribed, filled eighty pages. He had fifty witnesses on tap to back him up.* * *Jim Jagger stood up at three minutes to two, smooth and cheerful. He explained that there were only three key portions to this case: Christie Downs, ballistics testimony and crime lab evidence, and Diane Downs herself.Yes. Yes and yes, Jagger admitted. Of course, there had been lovers. No one is denying that and names would be named.The ladies of the gallery reacted by shaking their heads in shock and covering their foreheads with their hands. One murmured, “My God!” Their own horror delighted them. The long wait in line had been worth it.Yes, Jagger allowed, there had been an obsession with a male—but never to the exclusion of Diane’s children, or her career. Jim Jagger agreed that Diane was promiscuous. He had no other choice—just as he must now explain the face that Diane Downs presented to the world. He cannot alter the protective smiling mask she wears. Nor is there any way he can keep her off the witness stand. Jagger told the jury that Diane learned to hide her real emotions because she was molested by her father. They must not judge her by the way she reacts in court.“She cannot react to pain by crying. She laughs, she jokes; everything is going to be okay—this is her habitual reaction.”There would be tapes. “When we listen to the tapes … you’ll see she talks without thinking.”Both sides had their own reasons for revealing as much about Diane as possible. Jagger hoped to evoke sympathy for a girl who had endured such a hard life that her quirks were not only understandable but forgivable.“From my side,” Hugi recalled after the trial, “I saw her as a classic case of child abuse—perpetuating that abuse. Each side felt that the more the jury knew about Diane, the better his case would be—that was why there were so few objections during the trial.”* * *As Jim Jagger fought to save her, Diane’s blond head bent over her yellow legal pad. She was drawing something. It was a desperate face marked with shadows and heavy lines.* * *Indeed, there was a man—a stranger, Jagger assured the jury. He doesn’t know who he was or why he shot Diane’s children. “Whether crazy, drugged or whatever—he just shot. Christie Downs has—she has in fact identified the perpetrator as best she could.”Diane nodded but did not lift her face as she focused on her drawing.Jagger spoke of the trouble Diane had had with dreams after her desperate race to the hospital to save her children—a mother, hopelessly, helplessly, trying to save those she loved more than anyone in the world, confused later by her own nightmares.Diane asked for a Kleenex, yet her eyes seemed dry.“I suggest to you that she [Christie] has identified who did it—in a special way. And we’ll get to that in the trial.”Both sides agreed. It would fall upon the fragile shoulders of Christie Ann Downs.* * *On Monday morning, May 14, Judge Foote, the jury, and Diane boarded a yellow school bus. They were driven to Old Mohawk Road. The jurors piled out and looked at the river, the trees, and the narrow roadway that looked so normal now. This was the precise week when it all happened, only one year later. The maple leaves were not, of course, the same maple leaves, but they looked the same as they had the year before.Diane remained in the bus, her face an inscrutable mask as she gazed out the window.At the Lane County Public Works shop, the jurors looked at the shiny red Nissan Pulsar where it had been parked for a year. The car had been washed in the interim, and the outside rocker panel on the passenger side removed for Jim Pex’s analysis of the blood spatters found there.* * *Back again in the courtroom, Heather Plourd, the first witness, took the stand. “It was about dark. I saw somebody driving up in the driveway … She [Diane] said she was out sightseeing.”She described her visit to Diane in the hospital, the morning after the shooting. Diane had voiced a fear. “She told me, ‘I’m afraid Christie might blame me for what happened … When Christie raised up, I’m the first person she saw.’”Delores Holland, Heather’s neighbor remembered firmly when she heard the car door slam and the sound of tires leaving the Plourds’ driveway. “Twenty minutes to ten.”This early testimony was important in matters of establishing time but not sensational. Jurors #6 and #12 took notes, while the other ten pairs of eyes moved from Jim Jagger to the witness.Joseph Inman was next. His full beard was reddish brown, and he wore wire rim glasses. When he spoke, it was with a Texas drawl, not unlike Lew Lewiston’s. He wore western boots and a cowboy belt buckle. He was a good witness. He described coming up behind the red car with the red Arizona plates that was merely creeping along Old Mohawk. Inman identified photos of the Downs car as the car he saw.Deputies carried in a huge map, eight feet long and three feet wide, an overview of the vital areas in this case: Diane Downs’s duplex on Q Street, Heather Plourd’s mobile home on Sunderman Road, the spot where the .22 casings were found on Old Mohawk Road, the point at which Joe Inman observed Diane’s red car inching along the road, and the hospital.The times the victims had been at each point were noted on the chart, so that the jury could see for themselves.The shooting had to have occurred at five minutes to ten. It was 10:15 when Joe Inman first observed Diane’s car. He followed her for two-tenths of a mile for two minutes at a speed of six miles an hour. At 10:17 P.M., he reached a straight spot in the road and passed her.Diane was only four and a half miles from the hospital at that point, and yet it took her almost twenty-two minutes longer to reach the Emergency entrance.Jim Jagger attempted to sway Joe Inman on his recall of the time and speed. He could not. Inman would not equivocate.* * *Judy Patterson was the first of the McKenzie-Willamette ER witnesses. She was nervous, but she remembered it all—the Code 4, the page for all available personnel, and her conversations with Diane.“She told me the kids were laughing and talking, laughing at something Danny had said—and talking to Christie. That it was an awful thing to be laughing one minute, and the next …”Patterson recalled the two versions of the shooting Diane gave. After she had stepped down from the witness stand, she realized she had forgotten to mention one shocking exchange. Much later, she confided, “Diane looked up at me, that first night, and asked flatly, ‘Are they dead yet?’ No emotion. Just, ‘Are they dead yet?’”One after another, the employees who were in the ER a year before took the stand. Shelby Day was next. She had dreaded testifying, but she spoke clearly as she recalled that Cheryl was dead on arrival, with blood already clotted in her throat and a flat line on the heart monitor.Rosie Martin told the jury about her first sight of Diane standing by the driver’s side of her car. “I asked her what was going on, and she said, ‘Somebody just shot my three kids—’”Rosie had suctioned Christie Downs’s occluded airway. And then she had spent most of her time with Dr. Foster as he worked over Danny.What did she remember about Diane Downs’s wound, Hugi asked.“I just remember an entrance and an exit—somewhere on the forearm … She asked how the children were, and I told her the doctors were in there working on them. And then she—the mother—laughed, and she said, ‘Only the best for my kids!’ and she laughed again and said, ‘Well, I have good insurance.’ I thought it was peculiar—but I was thinking about the kids.”When asked about the Diane’s demeanor, Rosie replied, “She seemed very composed.”As the hospital personnel continued their testimony about the tragic night and shared the bizarre comments of the defendant, the jurors become more and more subdued.At afternoon break, no one in the gallery left.Diane never wore handcuffs into the courtroom, but there was always a faint rattle of chains just before she entered after the recesses. Every time she walked in, she smiled.Dr. John Mackey was to be the next scheduled witness. But his beeper sounded, and he rushed from the corridor on an emergency. Court recessed early. The gallery dispersed reluctantly, the spectators aware of the slim chance of claiming a seat the next morning.* * *Tuesday, May 15.The lines were longer on Day Six. A huge crowd pushed against the rope barrier an hour before the courtroom doors were due to open.Mrs. Mackey hoped to get in to hear her husband testify. A chatty woman who lived three houses down from the shooting site, half apologized for the neighborhood. “It’s real quiet—and nothing ever happens out there. This was so unusual.”When the doors finally opened, the jittery crowd surged ahead. A man who was far back in line stomped out when he found the courtroom filled. “I couldn’t find a seat,” he announced loudly to no one in particular. “There are three fat ladies taking up a whole row!” The three fat ladies stayed put but looked annoyed.Dr. John Mackey was a most articulate witness. He looked directly at the jury: “I found a small child gasping for air, crying weakly … and then I saw what I assumed to be a child—crumpled on the floor. I thought to myself, ‘Oh my God, there’s a third one. What will we do?’“What did you do?” Fred Hugi asked softly.“Can I refer to the children by name—it would be a lot easier.”“Of course.”“Cheryl appeared to be dead.”Diane was immobile, her pale right hand, with long, carefully filed nails, drooped languidly on her chair’s arm.“Cheryl—had dilated pupils, no respiration. We hooked her up to a heart monitor.”Mackey’s voice was emotional and husky. For twelve minutes, he described the measures they had tried. “I knew that Danny had been shot in the chest, I knew that Christie had been shot in the chest, and Cheryl also had been shot in the chest. Christie had actually begun the process of dying … the oxygen level in her bloodstream was incompatible with life … One of the most serious injuries you can have is a gunshot wound to the chest … we were just doing everything we could to bring those kids back.”One of Mackey’s other jobs had been to report to the mother what was happening with her children. Dr. Mackey’s encounters with Diane Downs had left him astounded. He told her all three children were critically injured, and that one of them had died—one of the girls. He started to describe the dead child but stopped, realizing how similar the girls were in appearance.“She said, ‘Oh. She was to be my athlete’ … She was extremely composed. She was unbelievably composed. I couldn’t believe she was a family member. There were no tears … no disbelief … no, ‘Why did this happen to me?’”Slowly, Dr. Mackey shifted slightly on the stand and turned to look at Diane as he spoke. “I told her that she would have to stay at the hospital,” and she said, ‘Well, will I be able to work tomorrow? I must work the day after at least.’ I thought that was a truly inappropriate response.”“Objection, your honor,” Jagger boomed.“Sustained.”“I felt—”“Objection!”“Sustained.”Hugi rephrased a question to elicit Dr. Mackey’s observation.“Objection.”“Overruled.”Mackey said that he observed a lack of concern by a mother for her children. “I felt that something was very wrong at that point—”“Objection!”They tussled with their legal points, and finally John Mackey was allowed to say a complete sentence or two about the woman he saw on the night of May 19.“A woman very calm, very self-assured, excited—not tearful—but angry. Occasionally smiling, occasionally chuckling. I saw a woman who appeared to be in very good control of herself. That’s surprising.”Fred Hugi asked if the police put undue pressure on Diane.“I felt they acted in a very professional manner … they were very cautious.”Asked about the normal reactions to grief, and he had seen many, Mackey said people tend to react in a similar fashion with crying and disbelief although men are less overtly tearful than women.On cross-examination, Jim Jagger attempted to modify the picture Mackey had painted. “All you’re saying is that during the five minutes she spent with you, she wasn’t reacting? Isn’t that true?”“Yes.”“Would it be fair to say this was one of the most serious and emotional situations you have been in in your years in the ER?”“Yes.”Mackey offered that he had already formed an emotional attachment to the Downs children when they were in the ER. “I’m that kind of person … We were very proud of the fact that we were able to save a couple of the children.”Jagger proceeded carefully. Mackey had clearly won over the jury. An overt attack on the doctor could be disastrous.On redirect, Fred Hugi asked Mackey if he was surprised when he heard that Diane was suing the hospital.“Well, yeah—we saved two kids … I felt we had been more or less heroic.”* * *Dr. David Miller was the next witness to take the stand. He had worked with Dr. Mackey on Danny and Christie when it seemed that they, too, were going to die.“Christie was as near to death as anyone I’ve ever seen and come back.”Dr. Miller related to the jury Diane’s reaction when he told her that the bullet had missed Danny’s heart.“She said, ‘Far out!’”Asked about his observation of Ms. Downs’s behavior, Dr. Miller said, “It was very consistent and remarkably unusual. She showed none of the cultural concepts of grief.”Miller’s animosity toward Jim Jagger was unmistakable but controlled. He explained that Diane made an attempt to remove Christie from the hospital and to bar access to the children by law enforcement agencies and CSD.“It became clear that Christie’s ongoing medical care might be compromised by attempts to remove her.”Christie’s custody had been given over to the witness and Dr. Steven Wilhite.* * *Wilhite, the surgeon who operated on Christie Downs, took the stand. He was a man with a presence. After racing to the hospital, he had found Christie with no blood pressure and no pulse. Her pupils were dilated, and her skin blanched white.“Essentially, she looked dead,” he testified quietly. He described the emergency thoracotomy he performed to stop Christie’s bleeding. As Wilhite spoke, his voice took on a richer timbre. He described what was—for him at least—the typical reaction of a mother who learns that her child has died. “Their souls are just wrenched from them.” Diane’s response was “what shall I say—a bit bizarre.” Wilhite’s voice grew heavy with remembered emotion. He offered Fred Hugi three examples that gave him pause as he had confronted Diane Downs.“I think one example was her concern for her car—and then that her vacation was ‘spoiled.’”But the third example, the incident that had troubled him the most, was when Diane entered the room where he was treating Christie. She had turned to Wilhite and said, “I know that Christie has sustained brain damage, and I don’t want you to sustain her life.”“That was very unusual! And inappropriate!” Tests had yet to show any brain damage.Each of the three physicians had demonstrated that doctors do not become inured to tragedy. Wilhite bristled as Jagger questioned him about why no one had signed permission slips before the children were treated.“We’re dealing in seconds here—seconds not minutes— finding someone who will sign a permit is ludicrous.” Wilhite’s voice rose, and he cut off Jagger’s next question. “I didn’t meet Mrs. Downs until after surgery. When I’m in surgery, there isn’t time for chit-chat.”Jagger and Wilhite were wrangling in earnest.“What did you do after the conversation with Ms. Downs?” Jagger asked.Wilhite smiled thinly. “I continued to prolong life.”“Isn’t it possible that she said—if she has brain damage, is it realistic to continue to prolong life?”“No.”“But isn’t it possible—”“No. I said what she said,” Wilhite thundered.“No further questions.”* * *Carleen Elbridge, the X-ray technician, recalled her meeting with the defendant the first night. Diane Downs had worried about having her picture taken without makeup as her injured arm was x-rayed. Yes, even as her children were dead or dying, the mother was concerned about her appearance.Dr. Bruce Becker took the stand. Becker cared for both Danny and Christie in the intensive care unit. He explained what Danny’s wound meant. There was no motor function or feeling in Danny’s legs. He had lost organ function. He could not voluntarily control his bowels or bladder. The chance that he would be able to use his legs again was “very slim.”Christie had survived two chest wounds, a bullet through her hand, and a stroke affecting the left side of her brain. A middle cerebral artery clogged, and with that, Christie has lost the easy use of speech. Her right arm and hand were still paralyzed to a degree.Becker explained how Christie’s speech problems manifested themselves. He used an angiogram (where air and dye are pumped into the brain to show areas of damage) and a chart of the left side of the brain to give the jury a crash course in speech pathology after a stroke.“She searches for words. She may, for instance, find a symbolic value—she may call a pencil a pen. But her ‘feedback loop’ is intact. She will know whether she is right or wrong—but her signal process is delayed … Her comprehension is the same as it was.”Fred Hugi asked a very important question. “Do you have any evidence at all that she’s experienced a memory loss?”“To the best of our knowledge, it has not been damaged.”Dr. Becker explained memory, stressing that it is not easy to tamper with human memory. Stroke patients, those with injuries to speech centers, may not be able to say what it is that they remember, but that does not mean they do not remember.Christie Downs’s speech difficulties would be exacerbated under stress, Becker explained. She might well make mistakes, but she will know instantly that she has done so. “Even when I first saw Christie, I was aware that she knew of errors and that she tried to correct them.”* * *At the defense table, Diane flipped her hair from her forehead and toyed with a pencil. She was either truly serene, or she possessed an almost superhuman ability to appear so. She looked very pretty in a light blue, long sleeved taffeta blouse, topped by a maternity vest.She had heard medical testimony all morning—testimony that went into agonizing detail on how her children had suffered and how one had died. And she heard doctors and nurses say that she scarcely seemed to demonstrate grief.And now. She must have known what was coming.Christie.Christie Ann Downs, the baby who was the first creature in the world to truly love her, was her favorite child. Christie would walk into this courtroom, climb up on the stand—and what in the world would she say?Diane had not seen her child for seven months, two weeks before she conceived “Charity Lynn,” who kicked now in her belly.* * *After the lunch break, a shining gold unicorn statuette rested on the bailiff’s bench rail. Few in the courtroom understood its significance, but it was certainly an item of curiosity.Diane, of course, knew what it symbolizes to her. That gleaming unicorn was Cheryl—it meant that Cheryl would never die.All along Diane had told the television cameras and the newspapers about the love she and Christie share, about Christie’s extraordinary intelligence: “She may be the only one to get me out of this …”CHAPTER 36They had planned this so carefully, cushioning Christie between two doctors—Dr. Becker first, and then Carl Peterson, each to explain why Christie expresses herself the way she does. Fred Hugi did not promise the jury what Christie would say. He did not know what—or how much— she would be able to say in this frightening courtroom environment.“If there was ever a time that Christie might lie, this would be it,” Hugi remembered. “She could say she didn’t remember, to remove herself from the case—and who would blame her? She might be thinking that ‘My mom’s more powerful than the State. She got me back once [with that October sneak visit], and I’d better side with her because she’s the winner, and she’ll probably get me back again. Mom’s all powerful. Mom blasted me, but I probably deserved it.’ There were so many reasons for Christie to suppress her memory—and even to lie.”They had tried to make it as easy as possible for Christie. “We couldn’t ask too many questions, but we set the groundwork … to show if she doesn’t answer, that it isn’t that she doesn’t remember … We know she remembers—we can’t be sure that she will be able to find the words,” Broderick explained.They didn’t know if Christie could do it with her mother staring at her. Christie’s entire foster family was in court to bolster her.* * *Hugi suspected that Jim Jagger was deliberately dragging out his questioning of Becker, so that Christie’s testimony would be spread over two days. Uncharacteristically, he muttered an epithet at Jagger.Exactly three hundred and sixty-one days after she had clinically died, Christie Downs was scheduled to testify. It would take the rawest kind of courage for the little girl to climb up on the stand and tell what happened to her in front of a judge, fifteen jurors, and eighty spectators.And worst of all, her own mother was watching.All morning there had been a conspicuously empty space in the left side of the second row. Just after lunch, Ray Broderick lead a child to that seat. She was a very pretty little girl with light brown hair cut in a pageboy with bangs. She looked to be about nine. She wore a navy blue suit dress, trimmed with white lace at the collar and cuffs. The little girl sat down next to a teenage boy, also a new face in the gallery. He held her hand protectively.The room quieted, and then hummed with expectancy. Was this the child who would tell what really happened that night?Odd. Diane scarcely glanced at the little girl. Her expression was bleak this afternoon, and she covered her cheeks with her hands, so that it was impossible to read her feelings. But Diane was not crying.She knew this was not Christie.The little girl was Brenda, Christie’s foster sister and best friend.Suddenly, a door beside Judge Foote’s bench opened and another child walked into the room. Her outfit and hairdo were identical to Brenda’s. Christie looked first at the floor, and then, very slowly, she lifted her gaze. Her eyes met Diane’s. Mother and daughter stared straight at each other for a beat, and both began to cry.Diane looked away first, and Christie dabbed at her face with a large, lacy pink handkerchief, holding her left hand to the side of her face.Her right arm hung limp, useless.This was the most difficult moment of the trial for Fred Hugi. “I’m thinking about what she was like when I first saw her—and, before that, when the blood was gurgling out of her—and about when Diane had her for hours in October. And yet, Christie’s still HERE. She’s only talked about the shooting with me twice before the trial—and all those people are out there gawking.”Christie took the stand, lifting her dead arm with her left hand and laying it carefully in her lap. Her face was full of fear and pain and a kind of hopelessness. The stroke had left her with slight facial paralysis. One corner of her mouth drooped, making her words blur. She could say “yeah” more easily than she could say “yes.” Mr. Hugi had told her that would be all right.Christie occasionally glanced down at the defense table where her mother sat.No matter how much preparation had been done, no matter how many sessions with Dr. Peterson, no matter the presence of her dearest friend out there in the gallery. No matter that Diane sat smiling fixedly at her twenty feet away. Christie Downs was all alone. She could not stop crying, but she would not run.Diane leaned forward at the defense table and smiled harder at Christie.Fred Hugi walked close to Christie. She knew him. This was her friend, the same friend she’d visited for weeks, who had helped her get ready for today. Now, she looked into his eyes and took a deep breath.He did not know if she could do it or not. He did not want to qualify her as a witness yet. First he had to be sure she could speak in the courtroom. He would have to demonstrate to the court soon that she was competent. But first, he must cut the rest of the courtroom away from him and Christie, tune the gawkers out, so she can say what she must.Hugi’s voice was very soft as he began.VERBATIM:“Christie, do you feel okay?”(Witness nods head.)“You’re going to have to talk to all these people here. Can you tell me your name?”“Christie Ann Downs.”“How old are you?”“Nine.”“What grade are you in?”“Fourth.”“Do you know your teacher’s name?”“Yes.”“Can you tell us her name?”“Miss Bottoroff.”“Did you go to school today?”“No.”(Christie’s voice is tremulous, almost a falsetto. She is trying so hard.)“You had to come to the courthouse?”“Yes.”(Christie’s face is very red.)“We’ve talked about this day before, haven’t we? —That this day would happen? Have we talked about it?”“Yeah.”Hugi held his breath. He had to ease Christie into this. At grand jury, Christie burst into tears when he asked her only to say her name.“Okay. Christie, do you remember back to the day when you got shot? Can you remember?”“Yes.”“Do you remember if you went to school that day or not?”“Yes, I did.”“Do you remember where you went when you came home from school?”“Yeah.”Judge Foote interrupted Hugi’s questioning to remind him to inquire as to Christie’s competency.“Yes,” Hugi said. “I haven’t lost sight of that.”“Very well.”“The Judge wants me to ask you some questions about if you understand the difference between the truth and a lie. Do you understand the difference?”“Yeah.”“If I said this piece of paper was black, would that be the truth or a lie?”“A lie.”“And you know that when you come in the courtroom like this, that you have to tell the truth. You understand that?”“Yeah.”“Do you promise to do that?”“Uh-huhh.”Diane had not changed expression. She flipped her hair from her eyes several times, watching Christie intently.“Do you promise to do that?”“Yeah.”“So everything we talk about in here now has to be the truth as best you can remember. Do you understand that?”“Yeah.”* * *The courtroom was so very still. But suddenly, the doors to the corridor creaked open, and a young woman tiptoed in, looking for a seat.“I lost it,” Ray Broderick recalled ruefully. “It was some reporter from one of the smaller papers. I told her to either find a seat or get out, and she said, ‘But I’m with the press.’ And she just stood there in the aisle. If she stayed there, she’d detract from Christie’s testimony, from everything we’d done to assure she would have the right setting up there. I still can’t believe I said it, but I turned to that girl and whispered, ‘Get the fuck out of here. Now!’ She left.”* * *“On the day this happened, you went to school, and you came home from school. Do you recall that?” Hugi asked, his eyes never leaving Christie.“Yeah.”“Whose house did you go to?”“My grandparents.”“Did you eat there?”“Yeah.”“And after you ate, where did you go then?”“To my mom’s house.”“Back to her apartment where you were living?”Christie nodded.“Did you go out that night?”“Yeah.”“Did you go for a ride?”“Yeah.”“Who went with you?”“My mom, Cheryl, and Danny went.”“And do you remember the car?”“Yeah.”“What color was the car?”“Black and red.”“Can you tell us where you went? Do you remember where you went to?”“Yeah.”“Where?”“My mom’s friend’s house.”“And was that in the city or was it in the country—were there buildings—tall buildings—or was there a lot of grass?”“A lot of grass.”“Do you remember what you did when you got there?”“Yeah.”“What did you do?”“We went out and petted the horse.”“Did you give the horse food?”“Yeah.”“What was your mom doing when you were petting the horse and giving it food?”“She was talking to her friend.”“Do you remember her friend’s name?”“Yeah—Heather.”“When you left Heather’s, do you remember if it was light out or dark?”“It was dark.”“Who was in the car when you left Heather’s house?”“My mom, Cheryl, and Danny, and me too.”“Do you remember if there was any music playing in the car?”“Yeah.”“Was that from the radio or was it from the tape?”“Tape.”“And do you remember there was a time when the car stopped?”“… yeah.”Christie began to cry again. Hugi paused, and Christie took a deep breath.“When the car stopped, did you see any other people around?”“No.”“Did you see any person standing in the road?”“No.”“When the car stopped, what did your mom do?”There was no sound at all in the packed courtroom, nothing beyond Fred Hugi’s soft questions, and the witness’s tear choked answers. No breathing and, seemingly, no heartbeats from the jury or the gallery.“She got out, and she pulled the lever that went to the trunk.”“I’m going to show you a picture here. It’s called State’s #335. Is that the lever you’re talking about?”“Yes.”“After your mom pushed the lever that went out to the trunk, were you able to see her do anything after that?”“I didn’t look at the back.”“O.K. Did you see her come back into the car?”“Yeah.”* * *The next question was one Hugi had asked Christie only twice before.“It was going to scare her again. Here I was putting her through the meat grinder again—knowing what she was going through. Her courage was amazing. Now she was going to avenge Cheryl’s death, and put the killer away. The drama was more than I was up to.”But he asked the question, for the third, and hopefully, last time.* * *“What did you see then?”“She kneeled down and—”Christie began to sob, burying her face in her hands. Her sobs were echoed in the courtroom as spectators broke into tears too. Diane turned her head away from Christie.“Would you like a recess?” Fred Hugi asked his witness.Christie said nothing.“What did you see? You told us she leaned across the seat?”“Yeah.”“What happened then?”Diane was crying. Christie put her hand to her face as if to block out the memory.“She shot Cheryl.”“And you saw that happen?”“Yeah.”“Was the music still playing?”“Yeah.”“Can you tell us what that was?”Christie did not answer. Her face was scarlet with the effort to stop the tears and to keep going. But she could not say the title of the song that was playing on the car’s tape.“Maybe I’ll come back to that,” Hugi said. “Do you remember what happened after you saw Cheryl get shot?”“Yeah.”“What happened then?”“She leaned over to the backseat, and she shot Danny.”“What happened then? What happened after Danny got shot?”“She standed up and went to the back of the seat on the—”Christie could no longer hold back her tears. In the gallery, Brenda let out a wail of anguish and Evelyn Slaven cuddled her tightly, rocking her. Brenda could not handle Christie’s testimony. The Slavens’ son carried her out of the courtroom.Christie was not alone. She had Mr. Hugi. And Mr. Hugi was trying to help her finish what she must say.“Do you remember when you got shot?”“Yeah.”Her voice was thick, clotted with tears, and she held her pink handkerchief to her face.“Who shot you?”“My mom.”“Do you remember the music that was playing?”Christie was silent.“Can you just not think of it right now?”“I can’t think of it.”“Do you remember what happened after you got shot?”“No.”“I’m going to put before you State’s # 334. Have you seen that before?”Hugi picked up the golden statue from the bailiff’s bench and held it out toward Christie.“Yeah.”“What is that?”“It’s a unicorn.”“Where did that come from?”“My mom bought it for us.”“That was before you got shot?”“Yeah.”“If I said the name of that song that was playing, do you think you’d remember it?”“Yeah.”“Is it ‘Hungry Like the Wolf?’”“Yeah.”“No doubt about that?”“No.”“Christie, has anyone ever told you to lie about this?”“No.”“What you’ve said here is the truth?”“Yeah.”“Christie, do you still love your mom?”“Yeah.”Almost everyone in the courtroom was crying—from the burly deputy beside Chris Rosage to the reporters in the front row and the jurors.“I’m going to offer the two exhibits that were identified by the witness at this time,” Hugi said quietly.* * *Jim Jagger had no objection to the admission of the unicorn and the picture of the car’s trunk-release lever. He now had to cross-examine a little girl whose face was streaked with tears.* * *VERBATIM:(He begins)“Do you know who I am?”“No.”“Do you recognize me?”“No.”“I’m an attorney just like Mr. Hugi, and I’ll be asking some questions for your mom. Do you remember at all?”“Yeah.”“When was that?”“In the hospital I remembered.”“Do you remember if you told anybody—”“Yeah.”“—about it? Christie was hanging in there, fielding questions.)“He was lying on his side.”“Do you remember where Cheryl was?”“Yeah.”“Where was she?”“She was sitting up.”“She was sitting up?”“Uh-huh.”“And where was she sitting up?”“In the front seat.”“She wasn’t asleep?”“No.”“Do you remember what she was wearing?”“No.”“And you remember that—do you remember if Cheryl was awake or asleep?”“She was awake.”“Can you tell me which way she was facing—front or side or back?”“Front.”(Jagger conferred with Diane, and they nodded their heads. Clearly, Diane had suggested that Christie was confusing the fatal night with the other car trip, the trip they’d taken to the beach a week earlier.)“Do you remember going to the beach with your mother and Danny and Cheryl?”“Yeah.”“Do you remember the drive to the beach being a long ways or a short ways?”“It was long.”“Do you remember Danny sleeping—Well—forget that question. Do you remember that at all? Did you do that too?”(Witness nods head.)Christie laughed, her eyes turned down shyly. Then she glanced up at Judge Foote. He smiled at her. The gallery was getting restless and antsy. A woman in the second row muttered under her breath, “Come on! That’s enough.”“Okay. Did you practice sitting where the attorneys sit?”“No.”“Have you had some—when you were driving to your mom’s friend that night, were you and Danny and Cheryl— what were you doing on the drive out to her place?”“Listening to the music.”“What music was playing?”“The tape of Duran Duran.”Diane stared intensely at Christie. Her face was contorted, as if she was trying to convey something to her daughter.“Were you all laughing or talking?”“Not talking or laughing.”“Just listening to the music?”“Maybe we were talking sometimes.”“Do you remember if on the way out there, you got lost at all?”“Nope.”“Do you remember seeing in the hospital some things on the television about your mother and you and Danny and Cheryl?”“Yeah.”“What do you remember?”(No response.)“Do you remember if you saw any TV programs about it?”(No response.)“Do you feel like you know what the answer is to my question, but you just can’t say it, or maybe you don’t know if you saw TV or not?”(No response.)“Are you feeling a little tired?”“No.”“I wouldn’t mind if we had even a break at this time. I’ll be asking a series of more questions, taking more time,” Jagger offered to Judge Foote. “This might be an appropriate place to break. Fresh in the morning might be better.”* * *This was what Hugi had feared. Christie had dreaded the witness stand. He didn’t want her to have to go through another night of anxiety. Judge Foote agreed. He ordered only a ten minute recess.Jagger was going on too long with the child. He asked the same questions several times—obviously trying to show that Christie had confused the trip to the beach with the trip to Heather Plourd’s. He hinted that Christie had been coached until she was brainwashed by Susan Staffel, Paula Krogdahl, and Fred Hugi. But it wasn’t working.Christie knew what she knew.At 5:05 in the afternoon, Jagger began again.* * *VERBATIM:“Do you remember some time ago you being told by anyone—erase that—Do you know what a suspect—do you know what the word ‘suspect’ means?”“No.”“That’s the reason I want to stop for a second. Do you remember ever being told by someone that some people thought your mother was the one who shot Danny and Cheryl and you? Okay? The first one is this: Do you remember before you went to the beach if you saw that short gun in the trunk of the car?”“Yeah.”“Was that while you were getting some clothes and things in the trunk of the car?”(No response.)“Is it hard to remember back then?”“It was in the trunk of the car.”“Do you remember seeing it there when you got back from the beach?”“Yeah.”“… There was just one in the trunk of the car that size, wasn’t there—the smaller one?”“Yeah.”“Do you remember talking to Dr. Peterson about whether or not you could be safe with your mom?”(No response.)“Is it that you don’t remember talking about being safe with Dr. Peterson?”“With my mom? I was safe with my mom?”“Yes.’(No response.)“I’ll ask you again later, or were you going to—”Christie shook her head. Jim Jagger’s questions were impossible to follow, and she was tired.“… Did you go ahead and draw a picture of who shot Danny and Cheryl and you?”“I was trying to draw.”“And do you remember if you actually did draw it or not?”“I was not finished.”The bailiff started to hand Exhibit G, her unfinished drawing of the “Killer,” to Christie.“I’ll ask you—before you do it—when I—when I have a picture shown to you, I’ll ask you if that’s the picture you drew of who hurt you. Okay?”Christie nodded.“That’s the one that you drew of who hurt you, isn’t it?”“Yeah.”“… and that was the—even though maybe it wasn’t finished, it was the best job you could do on drawing that, right?”“Uh-huh.”“… Do you remember anything on the drive to the hospital?”“No.”“Things happened very fast, didn’t they?”“Yeah.”“Has anybody ever told you that your mom saw a person there who shot Danny and Cheryl and you?”“No.”“Has anybody ever told you that somebody out there within—a little while before this happened—saw someone who looked like the person your mom said did the bad things to you? Is that right?”“Yeah.”“Have you had dreams about this?”“No.”“You don’t remember—strike that—another erase, okay? I don’t have any more questions for you.”Christie was limp with exhaustion.Fred Hugi approached Christie on redirect. He wanted to let her go with no more questions. But he could not. She had been on the stand for such a long time, and it was almost 6:00 P.M.* * *VERBATIM:“Do you know who shot Cheryl?”“Yeah.”“Who was that?”“My mom.”“How do you know that?”“I watched.”“Were there any strangers there, anybody that you didn’t know?”“No.”“How about with Danny—was there any stranger there when Danny was shot?”“No.”“Who shot him?”“My mom.”“How about you—when you got shot—were there any strangers there?”“No.”“Who shot you?”“My mom.”“Do you know that because you saw her do it?”“Yeah.”“Was she close to you when that happened?”“Not close.”“In the same car—was she in the same car or standing outside?”(No response.)“Do you remember when the shooting happened, do you remember when Cheryl got shot?”“Yeah.”“Was your mom inside the car then?”(No response.)“Was part of her outside the car and part inside the car?”(No response.)“Are you pretty tired now?”(No response.)“I don’t have any other questions.”* * *Nor did Jim Jagger. Judge Foote leaned over and said, “Thank you, Christie, you can go now.”Hugi watched Christie step down.She had done it. By God, she had done it.CHAPTER 37“Hey, those people took cuts—hey! Get those people— they’re shoving and pushing.”“How unfair. That little boy could sit on your lap, and we could get one more in there.”After Christie’s testimony, the crowds grew even bigger. The State had leapt far ahead, and the followers in Diane’s camp were fewer. The bailiff opened the door at ten on May 16. A hundred people surged in and somehow squeezed into eighty seats.* * *Dr. Carl Peterson was the first witness of the day. He explained that when Christie heard the tape of “Hungry Like the Wolf,” memories flooded back. But she was afraid to tell him what they were.“I told Christie that it was okay to feel happiness, sadness, anger, fear.”Christie had drawn a number of pictures of Cheryl and Danny, of their car, of the pistol and the rifle. She had drawn the Plourd trailer. And she had drawn a picture of the shooter.Drawn March 4, 1984, it was not a picture of a male. It was a female with short hair and bangs, whose eyes have pupils afloat in white, whose mouth was turned down angrily. The gun was an excellent rendering of a .22 Ruger. The shooter held the gun in her left hand, not her right, as Diane would have, but then Christie herself was left handed. It was not a major discrepancy. The picture was incomplete. It showed the figure from the waist up only, the part of the body Christie would have seen from her position in the backseat.Peterson recalled some of the things Christie said, testing the waters. “’If my mom shot me, Cheryl, and Danny, I’d want to go back with her—’cause she was probably really, really angry, and it wouldn’t happen again.’”Jagger accused Peterson of planting a conditioned response in Christie’s mind to implicate Diane.No. Christie tested him, Peterson explained, to see if it was safe for her to remember. “She said, ‘Now my mom can’t be with her boyfriend because he thinks she done it—It almost seems like she done it.’”Dr. Peterson hadn’t commented. But on December 19, he’d asked her once again if she wanted to write the name of the person who had shot them on the slips of paper and put them in the envelopes.She had.And this time, she had not burned the envelopes. She had told him he could save them if he promised not to open them until she said so.After a counseling session on January 16, Carl Peterson asked Christie if she feared she might be shot again. Christie thought about it for a long time. “Maybe—if I lived with her again—but maybe she wouldn’t.”Christie had finally confided that she no longer wanted to live with her mother.“Maybe she didn’t really love the family,” Christie wondered. “She just loved Lew.”Christie wrote down two lists of people in her life. One list was a “safe” list, and the other was the “unsafe” list.SAFENOT SAFEMyself (Christie)DanielCherylDr. PetersonEvelyn and Ray SlavenSusan StaffelRay BroderickFred HugiMomMaybe my dadThe safe people were all new in her life—all but her brother and sister. Christie Downs had had no “safeness” in the first eight years of her life.On re-direct, Fred Hugi handed the still sealed envelopes to Peterson. Christie had given permission to open them.“Would you open the envelope dated January 2, and read what it says?”Peterson’s voice cracked as he read the question: “Who shot Cheryl? The answer written here is ‘Mom.’”“Would you open the envelope dated December 19?”Peterson read the contents: “Who shot Christie?” “The answer is the same. ‘Mom.’”“In the course of your entire association with Christie, has she ever indicated that anyone other than her mom shot her?”“No.”“Has she ever given any other version of the story?”“No.”“Are you aware of anyone influencing Christie not to talk with you?”“Yes.”“Who was that?”“Mrs. Downs.”“Has Christie expressed an apprehension and fear of her mother as well as love for her mother?”“Yes.”“Did she indicate to you the order the children were shot in the car?”Peterson nodded. Cheryl was first, Danny was second, and Christie thought she herself might have been shot twice.Carl Peterson testified that Christie said she enjoyed living with the Slavens because “they don’t yell or spank.”He had heard Danny say to Christie, “We might get shot again.”“Christie said, ‘Sorry, Charlie.’”(This was a slang expression derived from a canned tuna fish TV commercial that means “It will never happen.”)“I asked her how she knew that, and she said, ‘ ’Cause she doesn’t know the address of the Slavens.’”* * *Dr. Edward Wilson, who performed the autopsy on Cheryl, was next. As he spoke, the jurors paled noticeably. Diane was absolutely immobile, her hands quiet on the arms of her chair.Wilson’s photographs were accepted into evidence. “The cause of death was two gunshot wounds through the upper body, through the aorta. She bled to death.”Juror #12 looked nauseated as Wilson continued in his description of the last moments of the life of Cheryl Downs.None of the jurors—save #8—would look at the defendant.* * *The parade of police began. Police officers say “Sir” when they testify. They do not volunteer information but answer questions.One by one, they told of their contact with Diane Downs, of what they remembered of May 19, 1983. Most of them referred to notes as they spoke but only for specific details. The woman herself—who sat before them—they recalled perfectly without prompting.Rob Rutherford read from his notes. Just before he left the hospital with Diane on May 19 to go back to Old Mohawk Road, Diane had laughed as she said, “I hope you have good insurance. If I die out there, I’m going to sue you! And I’ll come back to haunt you.”Rob Rutherford continued on the stand the next morning. Jagger inferred that he did not look hard enough for the gunman and the yellow car the night of the shootings. Rutherford would not be shaken. He was adamant that there had been no sign that any vehicle had been recently parked along the road. The sheriff’s sergeant had just completed a tracking course.Tracy was next, and the gallery tittered upon hearing the name “Dick Tracy.”Tracy verified how incongruous the defendant’s behavior was, recalling her continual babble about a boyfriend in Arizona instead of concern for her injured children. Diane told them where the rifle was, read the consent to search aloud, and then signed it. And Tracy had taken it to Sergeant Jon Peckels.The best piece of physical evidence the State had was the microscopically identical match between the extractor marks on the casings from the death bullets and those of the two bullets in the .22 rifle home in Diane’s closet.Jagger suggested to the jury that the chain-of-evidence had been broken and the bullets mixed up. He asked for a play-by-play account of Tracy’s day. He was looking for a slip somewhere. Most defense attorneys don’t have the temerity of nitpick with civilian witnesses, but cops are fair game.Diane seemed either exhausted or bored. Her eyes were puffy with fatigue, and her arms rested heavily on her chair.“You didn’t make any notes about the order of how the bullets came out of the rifle, did you?” Jagger asked Tracy.“I did not.”“Detective Tracy, you’ve been investigating homicides where you know who did it—and couldn’t prove it. Isn’t that true?”“Yes …”“Isn’t it true that you got a bullet from the scene, from another officer present—and put it in the rifle?”Tracy’s face turned a shade of magenta. (You do not ask an honest cop a question like that.) “That is a lie,” he said evenly. “That is not true.”“Do you deny then that you could have placed two bullets within the rifle, or you could have placed two bullets in an envelope—bullets that didn’t come from the gun? You deny that, don’t you?”Tracy looked ready to go for Jagger’s throat. “You bet I deny that!”Dick Tracy had solved every murder case he had ever investigated. It was his last year on the force, and he certainly was not about to start creating fake evidence.Judge Foote pounded his gavel—for a judicious break.* * *Jon Peckels was next. He had twenty-one years with the Lane County Sheriff’s Office, assigned currently to the Identification section, and in charge of preserving the physical evidence in the shootings. At fifteen minutes to midnight on May 19, Shelby Day gave him one bullet, a bullet that had fallen from Cheryl’s clothing as she was placed on the treatment table. Dr. Wilhite had given him another bullet.Ever since that night, Peckels had watched over the chain of evidence. If even one link is broken, the evidence is flawed. He had guarded the children’s clothing and the bright colored beach towel. He had the gun residue kit and the trace metal tests made at the hospital at eighteen minutes after midnight.* * *Roy Pond slowly opened the brown bags containing the small garments. A miasma, real or imagined, seems to rise from clothing sodden with long dried blood. Pond pulled out a green shirt with a yellow collar with a dark red blotch in the center. He identified Danny’s Osh-Kosh-by-Gosh jeans and Christie’s maroon pants.Diane turned her head away and stared down at her hands. She began to doodle again on the yellow pad in front of her.Tears ran down Roy Pond’s face as he held up Cheryl’s gore marked purple and white T-shirt, cut at the seams by someone in the ER a year before, and then the postal sweater (Diane’s) that Cheryl had around her shoulders when Shelby Day carried her in.“These are the shorts from little Danny Downs.” Pond’s voice cracked. They are such improbably tiny white jockey shorts.Diane had not looked up since Pond began.* * *Diane’s ex-husband took the stand.Steve Downs was still a handsome man. Compactly built, he wore gray slacks and a navy blue jacket. He spoke quietly. Steve described his twelve-year history with Diane. Her expression indicated that she thought his testimony was a joke.Occasionally, Steve Downs was laughable, and Judge Foote admonished those in the back when they chuckled at his testimony.The marriage was good, and then “iffy,” and then bearable, and then bad. He was aware of his wife’s lovers. He had thought her a little crazy, sometimes suicidal. She tried twice to shoot him in a three-month period in 1982.“Have you beat her?” Hugi asked Downs. “If you have, tell the jury about it.”Downs nodded. “The first time—when I found her with Russ Phillips in bed.”Diane gazed down at the defense table.He described another beating. “She picked up the girls when they were living with me and left me a note ‘You are a%%%####&& father.’ I was gone—the kids were next door with a neighbor. I went over to her house—her mobile home. Cheryl and Christie were playing outside. I was pretty pissed-off about that … She was on the phone—ignoring me. I took the phone away from her and put my hand on her throat. Then we just really got into it. I pounded her—pounded her hard. There was blood. Cheryl saw me hitting her mother.”Hugi asked Steve if he had been convicted of crimes. He would beat Jagger to it.“Yes, I have, grand theft auto. I reported my car stolen to the insurance company. It wasn’t stolen. I was convicted last summer, in July, after the shooting happened here. Diane saw that I wasn’t in her camp with the whole story. She called down to the Chandler Police Department. I owned up to it.”“The mobile home fire—” Hugi began. “Tell us about that.”“Diane and I planned it. She talked about pouring gas on it. I told her it needed to be done with some discretion. It was started by me—in the bedroom … The insurance paid.”Diane shook her head in disgust.“Did you ever show Diane Downs how to operate that weapon [the missing .22 Ruger]?”“Yes sir. I gave it to her when she was living at the mobile home by herself … I got it back … I assumed it was on a shelf in the closet where I left it. She wanted the guns. I didn’t see any need for her to have them.”On cross, Jim Jagger asked Steve to discuss the sexual relationship between him and Diane after the divorce.“It happened one time—it was very cold and callous. I absolutely could not bat against the guy [Lew].”For once, Diane agreed with Steve. She nodded vigorously. And then she grinned and passed a note to her attorney.Steve Downs admitted to stealing guns from Billy Proctor.“Isn’t it true that you were having affairs?”“No. Diane said that to justify her own affairs.”“You two have some pretty hard feelings, don’t you?”“Yes. They’ve [the DA’s office] showed me what they have and I’m satisfied with it.”“Did you look for that gun?”“Once the kids were shot, I looked for the gun.”“In a phone call a week after, she told you about what vehicle the gun was placed in?”“Yeah—it was her idea, and a wild one in my eyes. That gun was not in my house or storage place … I never looked for it until after the shooting, and when I did look for it, it wasn’t around.”“You wouldn’t have been inclined to give that gun to the police in any event—”“Yeah. I would have immediately given it to the police ’cause they could have matched the bullets to the gun … I knew then that she had absolutely nothing, no caring at all for the kids.”* * *The weekend arrived and with it, real spring, sunny, warm and full of promise. It was May 19 again.CHAPTER 38Diane’s due date was in July, but rumor was it might be June. Female spectators watched Diane with the eyes of experience to see if she had “dropped.” She looked close to term. The emotional strain alone would be enough to send an average woman into premature labor. But then Diane had never been average.She swept into court dramatically on Monday morning, May 21, dressed in a royal blue maternity dress patterned with flying gulls. She smiled at the relieved sighs in the gallery. She looked very well.It was the prosecutor who seemed to be wasting away day by day. Fred Hugi had lost so much weight that he had to cinch his belt several holes tighter. He could not hold down solid food, and he existed on milkshakes and yogurt. If he could have spared the minutes to run, he could work through some of the tension, but there was no time.He was scarcely eating, and he was not sleeping. Every night, like clockwork, he awakened at three with a throbbing pain in his jaw that brought him right up out of bed. He went to his dentist on May 18, but X-rays revealed no overt problem. His dentist, aware of the trial stress, diagnosed, “It’s all in your head. Ha. Ha.”During the day, Hugi was so wrapped up in the trial he could ignore the pain. But it came back every night. He was aware that tension can trigger psychosomatic pain, but this was beyond anything he had ever imagined. (After the trial, when the pain continued, he insisted upon another X-ray, and his dentist found the problem. Hugi had clenched his teeth so hard that he had split a tooth vertically, such a clean crack into the nerve that it looked normal in the first X-ray. An oral surgeon attempted a root canal filling, but the tooth fell apart. When it was pulled, the pain “in his head” vanished.)* * *On May 21, the courtroom was transformed. The mockup of Diane’s car was in place, filling much of the space between Judge Foote’s bench and the defense and prosecution tables. The roof was off and set to one side. This car was not red but pale blue, so that the outlines of blood pools would show. The names of those who bled there are written in. Just like the real Nissan Pulsar’s, the front seats were buckets with headrests, the back a bench seat.The dolls were in the courtroom. They were not as realistic as the car was, simply large white rag dolls that bend into different positions. Their eyes were black felt and mouths rosebud pouts. The Christie doll had hair of reddish brown yarn, and the Cheryl doll’s hair was made of lighter brown yarn. The Danny doll’s hair was bright yellow. They were exactly the size of the Downs children on May 19, 1983.“Cheryl” and “Christie” wore blue jeans, and “Danny” wore tiny shorts and small running shoes. A single lock of yarn had worked loose of its stitching and hung over “Cheryl’s” eyes. Unconsciously, Fred Hugi bent over and brushed the lock of “hair” away from her eyes. Hugi invariably cradled the “children” in his arms as he talked about them. Jim Jagger, on the other hand, tended to toss them on the floor when he finished with them, as if to underscore the fact that they are only rag dolls.It was a mistake. It jarred the heart each time one of the dolls crumpled to the floor.Jim Pex attempted to give the jury a crash course in forensic science. Pex and Chuck Vaughn had inserted a wooden dowel into a cutaway of a .22 Ruger semi automatic pistol, and then held the gun close to the dolls’ “wounds” to determine angle. A rigid white probe ran from the gun’s barrel through the wounds to show the bullets’ paths. Pex demonstrated on the rag dolls.It is a standard procedure in autopsy to help forensic pathologists ascertain the height of the shooter, his position, and the position of the victim. It is horrifying for the layman to watch. This morning, the jurors and the gallery could see the children as they were when they were shot.Jim Pex used an overhead projector to demonstrate how close the shooter was to the victims. With a .22 caliber gun, the maximum distance barrel debris (particles) will travel is two to three feet. All of the children had heavy stippling around their wounds.Pex used a number of tests to verify his findings: the Sodium Rhodizonate test (which turns purple in the presence of lead); the Greiss test (for Sodium nitrates); a soft tissue x-ray; the appearance of the skin itself; and the swollen fibers of clothing where the bullet penetrated.The gun barrel had been between six and nine inches from the wound in Diane’s forearm.The gun had been nine inches or less from Danny’s spine.The gun had been nine to twelve inches away from the two wounds in Christie’s chest (wounds so close together that they could be covered with a half-dollar piece), but only one or two inches away from the hand she held up in a vain attempt to block the second bullet.The gun had been six to nine inches away from Cheryl’s right shoulder—the first shot—but it had been right next to the skin, a near contact wound, at Cheryl’s left shoulder.Pex placed the doll children in the car mockup. Danny was on his stomach on the left side of the backseat. “He would have been paralyzed immediately upon being shot.” With the gun-on-a-stick, Pex became the shooter. He showed how “he” would have had to lean into the car to shoot Danny.At Judge Foote’s invitation, the jurors stood to get a better look at the demonstration.Diane looked away.Pex showed that Christie would have had to be sitting up on the right rear seat. The first shot would have knocked her into a half reclining position. The second bullet had gone through the back of her hand into her chest.Cheryl’s first wound occurred, Pex deduced, as she lay on the floor of the front passenger seat. In an almost reflex action, Cheryl had apparently reached for the door handle and tumbled out on the road. Cheryl had suffered a fatal wound to her upper right shoulder, but she was still moving. Her killer had either reached across the front seat, or run around the outside of the car, and placed the .22 Ruger against her left side and fired once more.Pex took the probe and shoved it through the Cheryl doll’s left side. The courtroom was as still as death itself.Because that wound was contact, or near contact, there was “back spatter,” high velocity blood that flew back from the wound to the rocker panel of the Pulsar, leaving a characteristic scarlet spray along the aluminum ridges.Either bullet would have killed her. The second shot could well prove her killer a liar.Christie could not remember seeing Cheryl shot a second time. But she had retained one remarkably clear memory. She was positive that a tape was still playing, even as the shots were fired. “Hungry Like the Wolf’ wailed inside the car, keening lyrics of thwarted lust. When Christie heard it in Dr. Peterson’s office, her expression had reflected a dawning memory of terror.Diane had always said it was Cheryl’s favorite song. Or was it Diane’s own theme song? Passion and longing and the mouth full of juices, the huntress on the prowl, the she wolf warning her lover that she would never, ever, ever, give up until she stalks him to the wall, and leaps upon him by moonlight? Fred Hugi felt that “Hungry Like the Wolf” had given Diane the courage to do whatever she had to do to get Lew back.It would have been the last thing Cheryl heard.Jim Pex found something interesting when he checked the condition of the tape deck at the Lane County shops. The tape deck would not play unless the keys were in the ignition! Diane had stressed continually that she put the key ring around her finger as she got out of the car to talk to the stranger on the road. She has related a dozen times or more how she pretended to throw the keys after the man shot her children.If the keys were in her mother’s hand, outside the car, how could Christie have heard “Hungry Like the Wolf?” Why did Duran Duran continue to sing as the bullets fired monotonously?Pex’s findings suggested that Diane Downs lied about throwing the keys. It made her whole story of fighting the gunman suspect. Could the jury pickup on the significance of that?Jim Pex’s next chore was to explain what the identical tool marks on the bullet casings meant. It helped to have gun owners in the jury.The Crime Laboratory Information System lists 12,000 different weapons and all of their characteristics. 3,468 of them are pistols. The best fit for the death weapon used on Old Mohawk Road was a Ruger semi automatic pistol.Several witnesses had said that Diane was the last person in possession of the .22 caliber Ruger semi automatic that Steve Downs stole from Billy Proctor. The casings on the road fit that gun. When an extractor pulls a cartridge from the chamber, unique scratch marks are left on the cartridge. When an ejector flips the casing to the right or left, it too leaves distinctive marks.Pex moved to the huge display board where enlarged photographs of the parts of a pistol, magnified many times, are mounted.“Nine cartridges were found at 1352 Q Street—in the Glenfield rifle,” Pex explained. “Two of the cartridges found in that rifle had been mechanically manipulated through the weapon that was used to shoot the children.”Despite the huge enlargements showing the matches in tool marks on cartridges from the rifle in Diane’s closet and on the casings of the death bullets, Chuck Vaughn was right when he warned Hugi that photographs would scarcely show a lay jury that those two cartridges had once been in the missing .22 Ruger. Cartridges were not as convincing as bullets.Pex admitted that the bullet Paul Alton and Doug Welch found under Diane Downs’s trailer in Chandler, Arizona, was too badly damaged to say it had identical characteristics to those fired on the night of May 19. In forensic science, a very strong possible doesn’t count.Pex had purchased a Styrofoam lined zippered case for a Ruger, placed a gun similar to the missing weapon inside, and put it into water to see if it would float.“It did—without even getting the zipper wet.”If the shooter had thrown the gun, in its case, into the Old Mohawk River, it might well have floated until it reached the McKenzie or the Willamette, moving gently north on the current that links rivers and reservoirs in a seemingly endless chain to the mighty Columbia.Possibly never to be found.* * *Diane supported her belly with her hands often now, as if it was very heavy. She had moved to Jim Jagger’s chair, so that she could watch Pex’s tool mark demonstration. His explanations tore jagged edges along her own script of what happened that night.Jim Jagger was on his feet, moving around the mockup and the display board, taking notes.Pex described spraying Luminol in the death car and along the roadway. It showed blood inside the car, and on the rocker panel, but, oddly, none on the road itself. Pex deduced that immediately after Cheryl was shot for the second time as she lay on the ground, the shooter had thrown her back into the car, before any blood had seeped from the wound. The initial bleeding was internal. The pool of blood on the floor of the front seat had come from Cheryl’s mouth.Cross-examination of Jim Pex was spirited. Jagger needed to shatter the theory that Cheryl was shot outside the car. He asked if the door angle might not have been different than assumed, if certain blood spatters might not have come from another source, at a different time.“That’s affirmative,” Pex said calmly, “if you have an alternative.”Jagger bore down on Pex. Jagger, the master of the scattergun, convoluted question, was at his best in this kind of courtroom warfare. Blood spatter, gun residue, ejector marks and extractor marks—all of it was already confusing to anybody outside a forensic lab. He obviously wanted to further cloud the issue, to ask Pex the same question so many different ways that the jurors would run out of endurance or interest to keep up.Finally irritated, Pex responded to one of Jagger’s long, long questions, “Well, we’re not talking about a basketball here—we’re talking about a liquid.”“Well, you recognize that some experts in the field would differ with you on that,” Jagger countered.“No, I don’t recognize that—” Pex’s voice rose a shade.Fred Hugi made no move to object. Pex was quite capable of taking care of himself.Jim Pex stared without expression at Jagger, who continued to question him about blood spatter, and finally said, “Perhaps you could draw this—you’ve got me confused.”Jagger wanted to get to the top of the mockup, so that Pex could explain where the blood spatter was. Fred Hugi bent to lift the heavy top portion, turning to Jagger to ask tersely, “Want to help?”Judge Foote stepped down from the bench to help lift the top of the “car.”Pex explained that the blood spatter on the roof of the car had been “medium velocity”—traveling at five to twenty-five feet per second. This was consistent with blood from Christie’s injured hand flinging back. The drops were much larger than high velocity blood spatter.* * *It had been an endless blue Monday. Diane seemed glum and dispirited. She had been kept busy turning her eyes away from displays. They were all over the courtroom. Dolls with probes through them, a car like hers, the terrible glossy photographs of Cheryl dead.* * *Diane wore a different outfit each day. On Tuesday, it was a gray and red diagonally striped maternity top. She always wore the red identification wristband of a high risk prisoner, but she made it seem a part of her outfit.For the most part Diane appeared relaxed, her right arm draped always over the chair. It stayed there sometimes for an hour or more, her limp white hand motionless. Her nails were long and unpolished, and her hair lank, the dark roots showing more. Her skin was flawed and muddy.The testimony was still about blood. Who would have thought that blood could be seen so many ways? To maintain a modicum of serenity, it was important to forget where all of this blood under discussion came from and to concentrate on only the scientific aspects of Jim Pex’s prolonged cross-examination.Yes, there was a blood spatter pattern on the exterior of the car. Yes, Pex believed that aerosol like spray on the rocker panel had come from Cheryl. Bullets free high velocity blood, blood that travels at more than twenty-five feet per second. “It doesn’t change much when the subject is moving slowly.”Laconically, Pex was saying that the victim can be almost dead, but his blood will still travel at high speed if he is shot.Pex patiently explained that he had tested all manner of objects for blood patterns: hand-whipped blood, a bloody sponge smashed with a hammer and with a sledge hammer. Pex tacked butcher paper up on lab walls and over lab ceilings to catch blood as it was flung from a variety of sources. Humans do much damage to one another with any number of weapons, and there are distinct differences in the way blood leaves their veins and arteries.Jim Jagger suggested that the blood on the outside of the car didn’t come from Cheryl’s being shot outside but was deposited there when Shelby Day lifted Cheryl out. The sleeve of the postal sweater must have dipped in the pool of blood on the floor and left those drops on the panel.No. That would be “cast-off blood” Pex explained. Cast-off blood is not like back spatter. Cast-off blood comes from a whipping hand or a dripping sleeve. Pex could not be shaken. “I made my opinion on the source of that blood the day we wheeled the car outside.”The postal sweater, its lower left sleeve saturated with blood was admitted: “Exhibit #53.”Jim Jagger picked up the Cheryl doll from the front of the red car, wrapped her in the gray sweater, and demonstrated how the sweater’s arms would have trailed through the blood, and then dripped on the rocker panel. Jagger must go through a most complex series of dips and whirls to make his point. Pex shook his head slightly.Finished with the doll, Jagger dropped her into a sitting position at the rear of the plywood car. The loose strand of yarn fell back over her face. The black felt eyes stared straight at Diane.Diane ran her long, sharp fingernails over her pregnant belly again and again, as if she were stroking and comforting Charity Lynn. She did this often now—caressing her own abdomen, and then raking it with her fingernails. It was somehow embarrassing—disturbing—to watch her.Danny’s blood was on the backseat, although there was very little of it. “The bullet clipped his lung. He may have lost blood through his nose or mouth.”Wait—if Diane was the shooter, why hadn’t there been more blood on the sleeve of her plaid shirt? Jagger was curious about that.“I made a paper apron, I held the gun twenty-two inches from the paper—the blow-back spatters occurred. [Closer up] I held the gun in my right hand—and I only got a few droplets on my sleeve. Most of the blood went up.”Pex was, of course, not shooting at a human body but at only a blood soaked sponge wrapped with plastic to simulate skin. More enthusiastic, and less sensitive, criminalists and pathologists have testified to the same experiments with cadavers and animals, a practice that instantly alienates juries.To refute further the theory that the blood on the outside of the car had come when the ER crew removed the children, Pex had tried another experiment: “I went to McKenzie-Willamette Hospital, and I poured a cup of blood on the asphalt surface. We stomped in that blood, and we attained some blood spatters on paper bags. We got spatters only two and a half inches up. We did not produce any spatters more than two and a half inches from the ground—eleven inches away.”Whoever the shooter was, Pex was absolutely convinced that he or she fired from the driver’s side, reaching around the driver’s seat or between the bucket seats.* * *John E. Murdock, Director of the Contra Costa County Crime Laboratory in Martinez, California, and one of the country’s leading experts in firearms and tool mark metals examination, verified what Jim Pex had said: Tool marks are almost as good as fingerprints.The extractor removes the casing from the gun after the gun is fired. Then the extractor is forced back to the ejector and out the ejector port, where the cartridge is removed. Murdock had examined the suspect cartridges, both from the Glenfield rifle and the death car, under a stereo binocular microscope for extractor marks on the rims.“The extractor marks were close enough so that I concluded all of them had been fired from a gun with an identical extractor. I’m quite comfortable that the same extractor made the marks. When the claw shaped metal moves over the softer rim, it marks it. If you unload a gun by hand—very, very gently—you may not leave a mark. But if you do it forcibly, you leave a nice mark. Every expert I consulted on these extractor comparisons agreed that it was a classic example.”* * *Diane sat placidly with her hands folded over her stomach as the California criminalist testified. She seemed unaware that the display board behind her, with the enlarged photo of a black Ruger semi automatic, was directly above her head.She was anxious for her moment on the witness stand. She could explain all of this away. She was confident that the jury would believe her.CHAPTER 39Dick Tracy testified again about helping Diane draw a composite picture of the suspect, using an Ident-a-Kit on May 20. “We began with the hair, and she picked a shaggy head of hair, and then she wanted more hair added. She wanted ‘meaner-looking eyes.’” They had worked over the first sketch for a long time, and finally, after changing the chin line again and again, Diane had said, “That’s close enough … that’s close enough.”Tracy was present at the daylong search of Diane’s duplex unit. All of the minutiae of her life, the stuff from the back of closets and papers jammed in drawers, now become Exhibits #220 to #333: letters, romantic cards, poems written for Lew, essays, calendars, half filled out bankruptcy forms, and polaroid pictures. Tracy’s voice droned as he read off the list of items retrieved.A television set and VCR were wheeled into the courtroom. Diane had reenacted the crime for Jon Peckel’s television camera four days after the shocking night. Dick Tracy portrayed the suspect. Diane portrayed Diane. It was a bizarre videotape. The slender blonde woman on the screen wore a sling supported cast on her left arm, and she laughed as she directed Tracy in how to approach her, changed her mind, and then repositioned him.“I’m throwing the keys, okay?” She laughed again.And then Diane jumped into the driver’s side of the car. She yelped and giggled. “This is worse than—”Her words stopped in midsentence. She had hurt her arm on the doorjamb as she made her “getaway” and it seemed that she was about to say, “This is worse than—the real thing.”“Cheryl Lynn was on the floor board in front … with a sweater over her. She was asleep at the time. Danny was sleeping in the back.”Again Diane laughed on camera. Nervous laughter?The television screen went dark. Diane was smiling a little—here, now, in “real life.” She trailed her talon nails up and down her belly.The court clerk carried in a portable stereo.“Hungry Like the Wolf” blasted through the small courtroom. The first sound on the tape is—eerily—a woman’s trilling, heedless laugh. “I’m on the hunt—I’m after you … I’m hungry like the wolf—”The act of murder is caught somewhere in that music, assaulting the ear unaware.Covertly, listeners glanced at the defense table. Diane was smiling broadly. It was enough to raise the hairs on the back of the neck. She whispered something to Jim Jagger, giggling.Why didn’t the sound of this tape make Diane cry—or vomit—or something?She jiggled her foot in time with the music, snapping her fingers. When the title phrase came around, she mouthed the words, “Hungry Like the Wolf,” in time with the tape.The song seemed to last forever, bouncing off the acoustical ceiling and walls of the courtroom. The arrangement features extraneous noises in the background of the tape. Sharp reports—like gunfire. A snare drum, maybe. And screams. On the MTV video, the piercing cries are the sound of the tiger woman in orgasm. In the courtroom in Eugene, Oregon, for those ignorant about the visual script, the sounds were gunshots and children screaming in terror and agony.Fred Hugi, who had barely glanced at Diane during the first weeks of the trial, turned in his chair and stared fixedly at her, his great dark eyes unblinking. She did not look at him.The sounds like pistol shots came again, and then the breathy words and the chilling, high-pitched screams. Finally, the tape sighed to its end.Diane still grinned, her foot still moved rhythmically. The courtroom was as silent as if it were empty. The jurors’ faces were gray.* * *Diane looked terrible the next morning, her skin green beneath the pallor, mauve tracing the circles under her eyes.Cops continued to take the stand. Jerry Smith, the detective sergeant from the Springfield Police Department who carried Diane’s first diary to her, the diary full of unsent letters to Lew, began the day’s testimony, recalling impressions of the night a year ago.Paul Alton testified only to those things that he has been able to prove. The jury would never hear about his frustration in digging in the heat beneath Diane’s trailer and of all the avenues followed to a blank wall. Alton’s presence on the stand was professional and dispassionate. He recalled learning from Steve Downs a few days after the shooting that Downs had owned a .22 Ruger semi automatic pistol, which Steve had last seen in Diane’s possession.Alton identified the Montgomery Ward sales slip for a brass unicorn.Lt. Bobby J. Harris of the Chandler Police Department had accompanied Steve Downs up to Eugene. The Arizona detective held in his hand a theft report filed by Billy Proctor on January 6, 1982, on a .22 Ruger. The serial number of the gun was 14761.87, Model RST6, according to the Chandler Gun Shop. Proctor had bought it on January 30, 1978.Harris verified that he had arrested Steve Downs on June 7, 1983, for car theft after receiving a tip from Diane Downs on the car theft insurance scam.* * *Paul Frederickson was a hostile witness for the State. Paul, who much preferred to wear his hair and clothes in “punk” style, appeared on the stand as the “All American Boy.” Short and slight, he wore gray corduroy trousers and brand new black shoes. His brown hair was as straight and short as Beaver Cleaver’s.Hugi elicited the fact that Diane had confided a great deal in Paul. She had told him she was going to change her story from one man with a shag haircut to two men in ski masks. Frederickson testified that he advised her, “If it’s not true, don’t do it—but, if it is, do it.”And Diane had assured him, “It’s true.”Diane had “morning dreams,” her brother told the jury. “The kids were all alive. Danny was walking. Cheryl had blood on her shirt—but she was okay. They were all running from someone—and it was always Cheryl who knew which way to turn to avoid danger.”As far as Frederickson could recall, the dreams dissipated after Diane began therapy sessions with Polly Jamison.“Did she display emotion—when she was in her room?” Jagger asked Paul Frederickson on cross-examination.“Yes—she was crying—it was muffled. To her, it was something personal.”“Muffled—” Jagger prompted. “How—”“It was muffled with a pillow—or something.”Ahh. Good. Jagger wanted to show that his client was capable of tears.“When it was just me and her, she showed emotion—but not with my parents … In our family—my dad’s quite the tough type person … with a strong, bold front. He feels you should be able to contain your feelings and remain professional. Sadness and that stuff should remain private.”* * *Cord Samuelson’s fleeting affair with Diane had come back to haunt him. It was excruciatingly embarrassing for him to take the witness stand. Fortunately, Samuelson had already confessed his indiscretion to his wife.“It was the day before the grand jury hearing,” Samuelson recalled. “Diane came out on my route, and she asked me, ‘Do you want to know what really happened?’“I told her I thought I already knew. And then she said, ‘It wasn’t a shaggy haired stranger—there were two men with ski masks. They called me by name, and they referred to my tattoo. They said, “If Steve can’t have the kids, neither can you,” and they began to shoot. ‘They said, “Watch this, bitch,” and they started shooting the children.’“I asked her, ‘Why don’t you tell the police?’“And she said, ‘As crazy as it may seem, I want to protect Steve—because of the trouble he’s already in— because of the arson charges.’“I advised her to tell the cops the truth, and she said that her lawyer said it doesn’t look good to change your story in the middle of a murder case. She told me not to tell anyone what she’d told me. She was convinced the cops didn’t have the murder weapon. She asked me, ‘How can they prove it without a murder weapon?’”“You were quite familiar with Diane Downs prior to the shooting?” Fred Hugi asked.“Yes.”Tactfully, Hugi left it at that.* * *“Call Lewis Lewiston.”The gallery gasped. No, it was more a wave of sighs. He was actually here—the male lead of Eugene’s “General Hospital.”Just as unabashedly curious, the entire press bench turned to gaze toward the double doors at the back of the room.
