Judge Foote rapped his gavel for order. Diane had not moved, or turned her head even slightly.Lew strode in from the corridor and, despite Foote’s warning, the sighs reached a crescendo. He looked the part—every inch the southwestern hero, tall and tanned, his beard and moustache trimmed neatly. If he was nervous, he didn’t betray it as he moved forward to be sworn.“I can’t believe it’s really him,” a woman breathed. “Right here in Eugene.”Somehow, sometime, during the weeks of being cloistered in the windowless courtroom, reality had drifted away for many of the spectators. They were totally caught up with the leading characters. The trial had become fiction, an exciting diversion from their own lives.Hugi stepped almost immediately into Lew’s intimate life. They must sting, these questions about the affair that began when he broke his elbow in 1982.When Lew spoke, his voice was a rumbling drawl.“My wife became aware of it on my birthday, September 12th. I told my wife I was having an affair because Diane accused me of giving her gonorrhea. I said no … [but] I had to tell my wife because I’d probably given it to her. On September 13th, I tried to break it off. A gun discharged in Diane’s trailer that day.”There was no need for Lew to give the details of that gunfire. Steve had already testified to Diane’s hysterical despair when Lew left her for the first time.But the affair had continued. It accelerated, Lewiston said. Diane pushed him to leave his wife, to file for divorce. Sometimes he said he would, but he changed his mind. Back and forth, he’d wavered, with Diane pulling at him.The children?“I didn’t see very much of the kids.”“From Christmas on,” Hugi asked, “how were the … two relationships?”Lew made a Freudian slip as he tried to frame his answer: “Worse with my life—er—my wife because I continued to lie to her. Diane wanted me to divorce my wife and live with her and the three children. I told her I just didn’t want to be a daddy to her kids. I never wanted kids, or to be a father.”A crimson flush crept up Diane’s neck, but otherwise, she showed no reaction. The man on the witness stand might be just another detective.Still, if one looked closely, they would note a tenseness in her body. Every muscle under the seemingly blasé exterior was taut. She leaned over to Jim Jagger often, whispering and laughing derisively. She had to act as if none of Lew’s testimony mattered. Who could possibly believe that she ever cared enough about this man to hurt her children? But, even as she worked to show disinterest and scorn, Diane’s eyes fell on the new, wide gold wedding band on Lew’s finger.She had not seen Lew for eight months. Lew, her golden man she once could not live through a night without. When he left the witness stand, it was unlikely that she would ever see him again.Answering Fred Hugi’s questions, Lew moved verbally through the seventeen months he’d known Diane before she left for Oregon. By that time, her conversation had become “an every-day push for me to get a divorce, sell my house, and get up to Oregon with her. She wanted me to do it quick enough to come with her. I always said, ‘If it’s meant to be, it will be.’ I just hadn’t made up my mind.”And the gun? What about the .22 Ruger?“The few days before she left—four or five days before— she offered the use of her .22 pistol to me. Her ex-husband, Steve, was not my best friend to say the least … Steve threatened to beat me up.”Lew testified that he turned down the pistol offer after considering the gift for a few minutes. “I saw it in the trunk of her Datsun the night before she left—the .22 Ruger.”“What day did she leave?”“April 2, 1983.”Once Diane was in Oregon, Lew recalled, “It was basically a relief that she was gone, and I started to patch things up with my wife. Diane usually called me every day in the morning or evening. She sent letters every day. I began to refuse both the calls and return the letters. I was back with my wife in two weeks.”As Lew explained that her absence was “basically a relief,” Diane’s armor cracked visibly for the first time since he began to testify. She stared at him with an expression of ineffable sadness. He had not missed her. He’d been only relieved.Diane came back once, Lew continued, to give him his gold chain. “After she left on the twenty-eighth, I assumed it was over. She gave back the chain. I didn’t want to come to Oregon, and I was back with my wife.”Lew recalled the morning he learned of the shooting. “Diane sounded the same. She asked me, ‘How are things? How is Chandler?’ and she said, ‘See, I’ve been leaving you alone. No letters. No calls.’ And I said, ‘Why did you call?’ and that’s when she told me about the shooting.”“Did she sound upset?” Hugi asked.“Not at all.”There was a whhsshing sound in the courtroom. Not a sigh—more a massive intake of breath.Hugi questioned Lew about the rose tattoo on his shoulder, and Lew nodded. Diane got her tattoo first and had his name written beneath it. For months, she had begged him to get one too. After a few drinks one night, he’d agreed to go with her to get the rose tattoo. But he had refused to have her name written underneath as she had wanted.“Is there a name under your tattoo now?”“Yes.”Diane froze, listening.“What is it?”Lew stared down at Diane and spoke deliberately. “Sweet Nora.”Her chin snapped up as she took the blow. Instantly, she recovered, nodding with bitter weariness, as if to say, “I knew it all the time—I knew he’d buckle under to her.”Lew lifted the lid from the box of dried roses and nodded. This was the box Diane brought to show him when she flew down to return his chain.He identified the uncirculated 1949 silver half-dollar found in the glove box of her car. “I gave it to her—that’s the year I was born.”And then a virtual torrent of letters from Diane to Lew were presented. Some had been mailed, others hand delivered to him. Many were letters she’d written before she left and hidden in his drawers, in his bathroom and all over his apartment, for him to find and read after she was gone, a web of words left behind.The longer Lew talked (hours on the witness stand), the deeper his voice grew with strain and fatigue.* * *Jim Jagger suggested to Lew that Diane was not nearly as obsessed with him as the prosecution would have the jury believe. Diane whispered and prompted during this period of cross-examination.“You spent only an hour or two with her?” Jagger asked referring to their usual daily meetings.“No sir.”“How late?”“In my apartment, she would spend the night.”“When you were living with your wife, how late did you get home?”“At that time, it [the assignations] would be after work. When I was with my wife, Diane and I were together eight hours a day at work and two more after, on the average.”Jagger stressed that this was a married man, who had lied to his good and faithful wife all the while he had seduced Jagger’s vulnerable client.The defense attorney elicited answers that showed Lew actually liked children, inferring that the State’s purported motive, that Diane shot her children so that Lew would come back to her, was patently ridiculous. Lew countered that he never wanted to have his own children. Diane had always said she didn’t need him to be the father of her family. Yes, once he’d said: “Maybe I could give it a try—”“You see her as being just incredibly in love with you?” Jagger asked, sarcasm heavy in his voice.“Yes sir.”“She told you she loved you at least twenty times a day?”“Yes sir.”Lew testified that just before Diane had left for Oregon he had told her that Nora simply wouldn’t give him a divorce, not until “she was good and ready.”“What was Diane’s reason for leaving Arizona and going to Oregon?”“So that I could make some decision about leaving my wife and going to Oregon.”Jagger hammered at Lew. Wasn’t Diane’s moving away without any fuss at all the ultimate fair play—strange behavior for a woman who told Lew she loved him twenty times a day, for a woman Lew characterized as so incredibly in love with him?“Yes sir.”“Were you aware of any other intimate relationships Diane Downs had while she was involved with you?”“No sir.”(And, indeed, Lew was not aware of her later affairs. He did not know how quickly Diane had bedded down with Cord Samuelson.)Lew Lewiston was on the witness stand most of Wednesday. The tangled debris that he and Diane had made of their affair, details of his marriage and of her children’s lives, were laid out for the jury (and the gallery) in meticulously painful detail. Lewiston, a man who hated dissension, had found that once he began with Diane, there was nothing but dissension in his life.He admitted that he worried after the shooting that Diane or the police might implicate him as a suspect, adding that later his biggest fear was that Diane might come gunning for him or, worse, for Nora. “I was afraid that if Diane could shoot these children, the only other obstacle in her way would be my wife, that’s why I made the tapes.”Sitting there in his gray blue suit, his pale blue shirt, navy tie, and beige boots, this bearded witness resembled more a wealthy rancher than a mailman, the ex-lover of an accused murderess. Lewiston had made no effort to paint himself any more honorable than he was. He would not forgive himself. He would never believe that he was not in some way responsible for what had happened. Perhaps allowing himself to be so mercilessly exposed in this courtroom was an unconscious penance. There was a gritty honesty in the man’s description of a time in his life that was less than honest.It was finally over, and Lewiston stepped gratefully down from the stand. As he headed for the doors, he was, for the time it takes to draw a quick breath, within two feet of Diane.Surely, she would turn and watch him walk away.She did not turn around. And still, when the doors shut behind him, she flinched almost imperceptibly. So many times Diane feared that Lew had left her. This time, he was gone.Really gone.* * *“When I finished testifying,” Lew remembered, “and I was walking down the street, these two women drove by. Now, I was thinking I was invisible. I didn’t know anyone in Eugene—except the detectives and the DA, and … Diane. We just wanted to get on a plane and go home. I didn’t realize I was public property. People recognized me.“These women yelled out the window, ‘Way to go, Lew! Way to go!’ It was so strange—just cheering for me, like that. Like it didn’t matter about the kids … It made us want to get out of there and go home even more.”CHAPTER 40The court clerk began to play the tapes on Thursday morning. There were twenty-five tapes, some of them over two hours long. The proliferation of tapes was in direct proportion to the loquaciousness of the defendant. It was a kind of black farce. The detectives had taped their interviews with Diane. She had recorded her own tapes to double-check their tapes. Lew had taped her phone calls to give to the police, and Diane had taped Lew because she didn’t really trust him. And, in between, she carried on a running taped diary.As the jurors were each handed a hugely thick, black binder full of tape transcripts (so that they could follow via the printed word as they listened to the spoken voices) it looked as though the trial would last the whole summer.Reporters pulled out fresh, yellow legal pads and scribbled frantically as the gallery settled back to listen.Diane had heard all of the tapes. She was a participant in them, of course, and through the defense’s rights of discovery, she had listened to copies of the tapes. Even so, it must have been humiliating to sit and listen to her own voice played back in the courtroom, unguarded, unaware—sometimes manipulative and wheedling, sometimes sobbing, sometimes angry and sometimes throaty with unspent passion.Diane did not like her voice. It was a pretty, feminine voice, although she talked so fast that she often sounded like a 331/3 LP record played at 78 speed. It was impossible to picture her as the shy child she described.On the Lew tapes, he was unresponsive to Diane’s constant calls, to her breathy declarations of love. Couldn’t she hear that? Why did she bat herself against such an inhospitable source of warmth—like a moth with one wing paralyzed by the glow? Did she truly not recognize the goodbye in his voice?* * *Days later, the tapes were nearly finished. The last tape played. It was the hardball interview, which was hours long.  But the jury and gallery listened patiently. No one wiggled. No one coughed.The jury appeared puzzled when they heard Diane’s response to the detective’s question about the “suspect.” “You know this person?” Doug Welch asked her.“Yes I do … and I’m leaving because I do. Goodbye!”Why would Diane keep that information to herself?The State had called thirty-three witnesses. Four hundred and twenty-eight items of evidence had been logged. On the last day of May 1984, Fred Hugi stepped aside. The prosecution rested.* * *“Diane Downs!”He was going to let her on the stand. The moment she got on the witness stand, the door would be opened to questions from Fred Hugi. Diane didn’t care. She had to explain.She made her way to the witness stand. She was a bit more ponderous than on the first day of the trial. Her slender ankles seemed too delicate to support her gravid belly. Diane wore a navy blue, print tent dress with a ruffled white bodice. She looked very young and very sweet.She gave her age, twenty-eight, and her birth date, August 7, 1955.“How do you feel?” Jagger began.“Scared …” she answered in a high light voice.“Anything else?”“Glad to finally be here—It’s been a long wait. Scared— and anxious to finally have a chance to say what really happened.”“What does ‘control’ mean to you—the word ‘control’?” Jagger asked suddenly.“Control is just you don’t show emotion. You don’t show you’re hurting or people may hurt you more.”“You really believe that?”“Yes.”“Are you a trusting person?”“No … it depends on the person, I think.”“Do you like that part of you?”“No, you don’t find many friends … You go out of your way to trust certain people, and you get hurt worse … You don’t like people telling you what to do—anyway I don’t.”Diane’s favorite poem was the one about how easy she was to read, the one that ended, “Speak of me as you find.” But all through the prosecution’s case, she had smiled and laughed at inappropriate moments. If the jury went with her poem’s sentiment, Diane didn’t have a prayer. Jagger attempted now to draw out a frightened little girl from behind the insolent mask.Was she aware, he asked, that, even as he questioned her, she was smiling?“No. It’s not supposed to be there.” Diane laughed aloud.“Why?” Jagger asked. Why was she laughing?She blamed her father. “You had to sit or stand and listen. Don’t smile. Don’t cry. You end up mirroring what’s on his face. You learn not to have any face at all.”“You realize this is real serious,” Jagger reminded her.“Yes. Yes.” She was impatient.“But you say that with a laugh.”“They’re two emotions that are closely related. I’ve really never been allowed to cry—so I laugh. I know it’s serious.”And, again, she laughed.Perhaps she couldn’t help it. Perhaps she really didn’t know about the face the world saw.Diane told the jury about her early life, about her bullying father and her mother who dared not defy him. She had always considered her father an intruder in her life. Her parents, potential witnesses, were, of course, not in the courtroom as she discussed them. They were barred until after they testified.No, she had never confided to her mother about the incest, the fumblings and fondlings in the night when she was twelve.“I didn’t tell anyone until I was sixteen.”Her enmity toward Wes Frederickson laced everything Diane said. “Because of my dad, I can’t stand to be touched by dominating men.”Jagger asked her to discuss control.“I didn’t like it, and I’ve always been controlled by somebody else until I got my divorce. I vowed I’d never be controlled again!”“Do you like to control others?”“No. It can’t be done. Or I’d be dehumanizing them. Just to gain control over yourself is enough. People say I like to control and manipulate—but I don’t … I thought my dad was a terror—but he was Santa Claus compared to Steve.”“At the time they [the incest incidents] were occurring, how would you cope?”“Blank out. It just didn’t exist. I didn’t exist. It’s like a nightmare. Not real.”She explained she had never cried or fought back. Her father was the authority figure. She could not resist him. And she could not tell.“And so Steve dominated you later—Did you remain quiet?”“No. We’d fight. I’d end up getting hurt worse. I would almost fight until he choked me, and if I blanked out, and lay there, he said I was crazy.”“In response to your father, did you feel you had the opportunity to run away?”“Yes and no. I packed my bags five times …”“Immediately after the shooting,” Jagger continued, “you indicated on the tape that … was one of the most rational times of your life. Is that true?”“No. It’s easier to look back and see things as they really were.”“Why do that?” [Why tell the detectives she was rational?]“I’m a Twinkie inside. I’m soft. I try not to let others see. I don’t like people to think I’m soft or weak.”Jagger asked her about the incident in September of 1982 when she scratched at her face and shot through the floor of her trailer.“I turned my anger inside—because you can’t strike out at other people—so you hurt yourself.”“You never struck out at your father?”Diane seemed appalled at the thought. “N-o-o-oo.”“When people batter you with questions, what do you do?”“You go inside yourself. That’s the same as blanking out. You’re screaming—shut up inside. At some point, you can’t contain it, and it comes out.”“Did your father show softness, tenderness, or caring?”“No.”“Mother?”“When I was little.”“Steve?”“When we were dating. Miraculously, it stopped on our wedding day.”“Your children?”Diane’s face glowed. “Kids are different from other people. From the time they’re born, they cry for you; they need you. They don’t ask for anything in return.”Jagger asked her who had the children during those bad times that their ex-neighbor, Dan Sullivan, had testified about, when the kids were barefoot in the cold, and hungry.“Steve did. I’m glad that came out. Steve would leave them alone for two hours!”“Who were you living with then?”“Myself.”Steve had the children from September 1982 until the middle of January 1983. But Diane insisted that when she had the youngsters, they were always properly clothed and in bed by eight.“I was pregnant. We all went to bed by eight.”“What kind of a parent were you?”“The first year, I was learning—the next few years, I was a bad parent. Steve and I would fight and Steve would walk out the door. Then Christie would come sit by me, and I’d yell at her. Cheryl was into everything, and I was always screaming at her.”“What did you do about being a bad parent?”“Stopped it.”“Did you realize that things Steve and your father did might have affected you?”“Yes.”They talked about Diane’s essay on child abuse. She had written it in July of 1982 because, “It was important. People don’t have a right to do things to other people—especially children.” Diane lowered her eyes modestly. “I’m not a public speaker …”She felt better after writing the paper. It had helped her. “Even though I wasn’t the kind of mother who beat her kids with a two by four—but I wanted to say it.”Jagger had done well. He had shown a woman from a loveless home, sexually molested by her own father, terrorized by her own husband and pushed around and abused until she’d freaked out and struck out at her babies. But she had caught herself in time. She had even tried to stop other parents’ abuse with her essay. This was a good person, but a woman whose emotions had long ago frozen inside—somewhere back behind her derisive little laugh and her irritating smirk.“I can only see me from the inside,” Diane told the jury. “I don’t know how other people see me. I only know how I feel.”Now, after all Diane had already endured, the State had taken her surviving children away and was trying to send her to prison for something a maniacal stranger did to them all.Diane admitted she didn’t remember everything about that night and about going to the hospital, but she did remember there was no one to help her. Her memory of May 19 was spotty. Some things were crystalline, others obscured.She remembered filling out the insurance forms, but she could not recall telling Judy Patterson that the gunman had shot through the window. She hadn’t wanted to leave her wounded children and go back out to the scene, but “a nurse knelt and put her hand on my knee and said, ‘One might not make it,’ and I thought I might as well go … everyone was telling me to go—so that insurance statement was blurted out.”“Wasn’t that stupid to say?” Jagger asked.“I say lots of stupid things. I’m practiced.”Of course she had cried at the hospital. She’d begun to cry when her mom showed up in the little lounge next to the trauma room. She remembered coming back from the scene to have her arm treated. Dick Tracy and Doug Welch were there. When she first got back, someone told her one little girl was in surgery but that Danny would be okay.“They didn’t mention the other little girl. Doug said, ‘Did you know Christie died?’ I screamed at Doug—I was angry— sad because Christie wasn’t the one who was doing badly … I was afraid that if Christie was dead, then Cheryl would die too, and I’d lose both of them.”There was a definite pattern in Jagger’s direct examination of Diane Downs. He did not stay with a particular line of questioning for long. Whenever Diane began to smile, he quickly switched to questions about her childhood, or introduced pictures of her children. Jagger was using Pavlovian signals. He had to remind Diane not to laugh. He could not tie a string to her ankle and tug on it so instead he used photos and questions to pull her back.She had taken scores of pictures of her children. There were photos of Danny when he took his first step, and others of the two sisters, standing together. In one photograph, a laughing eight-month-old Christie was posed with a cat.Fred Hugi quickly picked up on the reason for the photographs. The wash of sadness that swept across Diane's features was instantaneous whenever Jagger handed her a new picture to identify. It was like turning on a switch.Hugi said, “I felt like standing up and saying, ‘The State will stipulate that every time Diane is handed a photo, she will look deeply moved and concerned. Now, let’s get on with the trial.’”Jagger asked a question that would seem a given. “Did you develop a real deep love for those children?”“Yeah.”“Did you ever develop a love for any man—like Lew—to pick him over the children?”“That’s ridiculous.”More pictures were introduced: Christie trying to eat right-handed; Danny and his sisters; Christie, two years old on a farm.“Do you miss the children now?”“Yes—very much.”Diane detailed the outrages perpetrated on her injured family.Jagger tensed. If he did not leap in at the right moment, Diane slid away on a tangent, just as she always had with detectives.She explained that she yelled at the deputies in the ICU because of her concern for Christie’s elbow. Christie had two bullet holes in her chest, a stroke in the left brain, and a hole through her left hand, and yet her mother’s main concern was for her elbow.“Her right elbow was really bad. She wasn’t scheduled for physical therapy. When she was shot the first time, she raised up. When she was shot the second time, she fell. I was concerned that she’d snapped a tendon.”Diane went back to the moment in the hospital when she’d had the worst news of all. But even after just one hour’s testimony, her story had changed. She no longer blamed Doug Welch for breaking the news.“They told me Christie had died. I flipped out. I sat there mourning for Christie and for Cheryl too. Then they said Cheryl had died. I said ‘Both?’ And they said, ‘No, Christie is alive.’ I felt like a traitor because I’d been mourning for Christie, and when they said it was Cheryl who was dead, I felt like Cheryl was standing there in the room, saying, ‘Didn’t you love me, Mom?’”Diane suddenly began to cry. For the first time in the long trial, she appeared to be mortified. She apologized for her tears and pulled herself back together with a smile almost at once.More pictures of the kids were presented in the afternoon session: the girls together; Christie with hair in her face; Cheryl grinning at the camera. There were so many photos of the children that the A through Z designations were used up, and the images were lettered Exhibits AA through ZZ.At one point, Diane smiled happily as she thumbed through and identified photos.“You’re smiling,” Jagger reminded her.“It makes me feel good to look at them. Those were the good days.”“Your children are handicapped?” Jagger asked later in the day.“Yes. But I want them back. That doesn’t change their hearts—that doesn’t change their minds.”Jim Jagger jumped into the center of the State’s motive theory. Had she loved Lew that much—“Yes, I loved Lew—even after the shooting,” she answered, cutting her lawyer off in midsentence.“Assume you believed the children were standing between you and Mr. Lewiston …”Diane shook her head vehemently. Lew was the original man who didn’t like trouble— kinks. “I loved Lew.” She sighed. “But he was a lot of work—a lot of trouble … I loved him, but talk about a headache …”She had left Arizona for Oregon simply to get away from her old life, not to force Lew into making a decision—only to begin again.Why did she say that?She had to remember that her first diary was in evidence. All of her plaintive letters, her aching loneliness and growing sexual need for Lew was documented in her own handwriting. At this point in the trial, after the long Memorial Day weekend, the jurors had already read them. She could not obliterate her old words with new words.And still Diane described Lew as a headache—too much work to bother with.Fred Hugi had had a good reason to read so many of Diane’s own writings in his opening statement, his dispassionate voice adding a touch of irony to the letters:She had written to Lew (this man she now denied so forcefully) from Oregon in the weeks before Cheryl died:You and I make each other very happy. We fit together so well. Yet you say you are willing to discard all that happiness because of my children. That is foolish. You’ve said all your life that you can’t live with kids. But how do you know if you can do it or not? You’ve never done it.Even you admit that I have good kids. They are obedient and well-behaved. I know that you are concerned about living in a little two bedroom apartment with three kids, but I’ve told you that by the end of August I would have a huge house to get lost in.The Nanny will take the responsibility for most of the kids’ spare time, and I’m sure you wouldn’t go stark raving mad spending a couple of hours a night with them.If it ever got to be too much, you could go upstairs and watch TV or we could. But I just find it so hard to accept that you would throw away our good feelings because of a fear that has never been proved …I’ll always be waiting for you. I’ll always say yes.Too much work to bother with?Do you remember how we used to snuggle up in your easy chair? I miss that so bad. It was so nice to watch TV at night and get all lazy before bed. Then you would tuck me in and give me such a warm, loving kiss.I love you, Lew and you truly loved me. I miss waking up in the morning and making love before breakfast. We were so happy … Why?She denied him now, as if she had never written that agonized, plaintive “Why?”All she had ever wanted was her kids, she insisted, and she sounded very convincing. Her words were right, but conflicting expressions flickered unwarranted across her features. Sometimes she wore one face, and sometimes another. And often, as she herself had pointed out, Diane seemed “to wear no face at all.” The courtroom artists, working briskly with their clutch of colored pencils, found no expression to capture. Their renderings emerged curiously empty of any sense of feeling, as if they had tried to draw a ghost.* * *Diane would spend an unprecedented four and a half days on the witness stand. She explained her entire life. She corrected, modified, set straight, and smoothed over things done (or not done) for the jury.Diane told everything.With Jagger’s indulgence, she recalled how much fun they had had on the beach trip a week before Cheryl died. She explained that that was why Christie was confused about when she’d heard the song “Hungry Like the Wolf.”“There were only six thousand miles on the car before the murder. We had four tapes: ‘The Beat,’ ‘Saga,’ ‘Men at Work,’ and the one with ‘Hungry Like the Wolf.’ We played the tapes constantly. We must have played Duran Duran’s tape for about four thousand miles.”“Did you have any guns—”“I brought two guns to Oregon—the .22 rifle and the .38 revolver. The .38 had cream color with brown carving on the handle … We took Danny’s kite to the beach … the .38 was in the trunk in clear view. They [the children] were in and out of the trunk all day. The .22 rifle was in the bedroom closet. It probably had no bullets in it.”Diane agreed absolutely with Jim Pex that a tape would not play with the keys out. Christie must have only thought she had heard “Hungry Like the Wolf’ during the shooting. “It’s impossible. When the keys are out of the ignition, the tape player’s off.”Jagger asked Diane if she was aware that she had “unnerved” some of the spectators in the courtroom by her reaction to the song.She smiled. “That tape has no bad connotations. That tape was Cheryl’s favorite tape. It can’t make me feel bad—I’m sorry.” Of course she realized that she grinned and tapped her foot and sang along. “I was just being me.”But when she spoke of telling Christie that Cheryl was dead, Diane began to cry again. She blushed. Talking about illicit sex did not faze her, but expressions of grief did. She hurried along with her story. “That’s when we decided the unicorn was Cheryl. Unicorns are magic. They never go away … The unicorn says ‘Christie, Cheryl, Danny, I love you, Mom’ … That was for the kids. They had a new free lease on life in Oregon. It was a new beginning.”Why, on the night of May 19, had she voiced her regret about buying the unicorn to Deputy Rutherford?“I said, ‘I shouldn’t have bought the unicorn, and maybe none of this would have happened. I meant that all the freedom, the unity—Maybe I was getting too arrogant, and God was slapping me in the face. The names engraved for all eternity was too arrogant—for the Baptists, God’s first. I put my children first.”* * *She had touched on the essence of this endless trial. If Diane truly put her children above all other considerations, then she had had no reason to shoot them. If, as her letters and tapes suggested, her obsession with Lew was paramount, the State’s case looked good.It would take a modern day Medea, a monstrous excuse for a mother, not only to shoot the three children of her own womb but to continue to play the martyred mother, to portray herself as a long-suffering victim and not a killer.Or it would take someone who had learned to blank out the ugly segments of her past, and believe that they had never happened.CHAPTER 41Another weekend interrupted the flow of the trial. Would Diane be back? Or had she been spirited away to give birth?She was not there. The bailiff looked solemn. The strain of testifying had brought labor on early, some decided. The gallery was restive and disappointed.“I didn’t wait in that line to see nothing!” someone complained bitterly.Suddenly Diane appeared, rubbing her wrists as if her handcuffs had been too tight. She was still with us but looked ghastly. Very tired. Very sad. Always before, she had walked into the courtroom confidently. Now, she only shrugged as the bailiff instructed her to go directly to the witness stand.The vibrant hue of her cherry red dress accentuated her pallor. Diane had learned that the child in utero was not hers but the State’s. “The Lane County juvenile court judge has ordered them to take my baby—the one who’s not even born yet. I won’t even get to see it. I’m angry and depressed—but I’m gonna fight.”From then on, Diane would cradle her belly more often. They couldn’t rip it from her womb. It was as if she had vowed to stay pregnant. If she did not deliver the baby, they could not take it away.* * *Jim Jagger moved to start again with questions. Diane sighed and picked up the story of her life at age twenty-two: the abortion of Steve’s baby, his vasectomy, her realization at the Right-to-Life booth, her rape by her boss, her seduction of Danny’s father, her triumphant pregnancy with the baby that was Danny, her surrogate pregnancy…From time to time, a juror blinked and shook her head.* * *Jagger returned to the aftermath of the shooting. Yes, Diane may have asked about going to work the day after the shooting. She always showed up for work.“I don’t know … it was a crazy night.”“That’s a light phrase,” Jagger reminded her. “Some people might not understand …”“No …” she rephrased rapidly. “It was a nightmare. I’m in a dream I can’t wake up from.”Jagger asked her about her feelings that night in the hospital.“Scared—stripped of all my power. I’ve always been able to control things—so my kids were happy, healthy, well fed. They weren’t listening to me. They [sic] threw Danny over [his] shoulder. I felt invisible. They kept throwing me out of the room … all the cops, asking questions…“They kept asking me how tall he was, and what he looked like. If they’d just gone out there with a tape measure and caught him, then they would’ve known how tall he was.”Diane accused the staff at the hospital of crippling Danny. A nurse deliberately picked him up, causing the paralysis. “This might not be the time for revenge—but I hope she burns.“I believe in God,” Diane explained somberly. “And He’ll give you anything you ask him. Danny will walk. I know he will.”Diane’s recall of the night in the ER room was completely at odds with the memories of the medical staff.“They kept comin’ up with real whoppers. They threw me out six times. I got up off the table, and they pushed me down. I never saw Cheryl until she was in her coffin. I still haven’t really accepted it—like they’re all in foster homes, or maybe they’re all dead.”She didn’t have the .22 pistol because she’d given it back to Steve. She wasn’t even sure how to load or unload it anyway. “If I never hear about another .22 handgun again as long as I live, I’ll be in heaven!”“How do you feel about talking about it today?” Jagger asked quickly.“Oh … I want to talk about it. I want to get it cleared up.”All she remembered of the shooter and the gun he held was an impression that the man was a “leftie” and that the gun was shiny.“How do you feel about talking about the attack?”“Sadness predominates. But I’ve told the story so many times now, much of the pain is gone.”Diane talked—on and on and on, inserting a stone in the mosaic of her life here, and a bit of colored glass there, and identified more pictures of her children.The courtroom was filled with women. Most of the jurors were female. Diane told her story to other women who had given birth and made do with too little money while wrestling with diapers, colic, chicken pox, and cleaning up vomit. Most had had less than perfect husbands. Most had suffered disappointments in love and in life. You could read it on their faces, a silent judgment. If that had been me …The women of the jury seldom took their eyes off Diane.Finally, Diane and her attorney had come to the summer of 1982. Diane talked about Lew, her confidences so intimate that she might well be talking to a girlfriend.Harm her children for love of Lew? It made Diane feel like laughing. “The two have nothing to do with each other.”What about the nanny? The big house? Jagger pressed.“Maybe ‘governess’ is a better word. I don’t know— Hazel,” Diane giggled. “The vision of the house got bigger the worse Steve got. I guess it was an escape.”Jim Jagger put the finishing touches on the portrait of the little family who had had it all, who hadn’t needed a father to make them happy.In Oregon Diane and the kids had loved to explore. “It’s fun to drive through all those streets on the hill above the park, and get lost trying to find your way out. The kids liked that. They thought they were lost—which we were—but I never told them that.”Yes, Diane had gone back once to Chandler but only to return Lew’s gold chain personally. “He told me not to take it off for anything—‘You’re my woman’ and all that mushy stuff. I gave him my word. And we all know what my word means, I think—”In Chandler, Diane had called Steve.“I had a couple of drinks, so I could tolerate Steve. I spent the night at his place. Steve and his friends were doing coke.”After a few more drinks, she had fallen asleep.Jagger urged her to expand on the events of that night at Steve’s. Diane looked down, hesitant.“Were you intimate with Steve that evening?” Jagger pushed.“Do I have to answer that under oath?”Jagger nodded.“I woke up cold, naked, and in pain. My mouth tasted horrible. I had a fuzzy head. I ran a cold bath. I can only remember coming out of a deep, deep darkness, and I was crying. I heard Jeff yelling, ‘Steve, leave her alone; she doesn’t even know what’s happening!’ Jeff didn’t help me, and I passed out again. When Steve took me to the airport the next day, he asked me, ‘Do you remember making love last night?’ I said, ‘No.’ And he said, ‘Too bad because we had fun.’”Why hadn’t she taken a cab to a motel? Why had she called Steve Downs to pick her up at the airport in the first place? Past experience had taught her there might be trouble.Fred Hugi noted the incongruity. He scrawled something on the legal pad in front of him.* * *The time had come to go over the night of May 19 in detail. Diane’s voice strained with fatigue as she recited the story again. She detailed the trip to Heather’s and the drive under the dark trees to the mobile home.“I feel that I’m relating something over and over and over—“The kids were in the car, and we talked through the window [after they’d petted the horse]. She asked me if Lew was coming, and I said, No, he wasn’t.”They left Heather’s at ten minutes to ten.She had shaved ten minutes off of Heather’s estimate. How would she explain the twenty-five missing minutes between leaving Heather’s and arriving at McKenzie-Willamette Hospital?She went back the way she’d come, south along Sunderman. But she’d turned away from town at the intersection with Marcola Road, thinking she would find the pass where Deerhorn Road went past a waterfall. But then, though Cheryl was still “babbling away,” she realized that Christie and Danny had probably fallen asleep.“I pulled off to debate where I’d go.”Diane remembered talking to Cheryl. “We talked about school, about her bloody noses. I said the next day she had off, we’d go to an ear-nose-and-throat specialist. She wanted to go for a ride still. But she was pretty easy. She was going to take the unicorn to school the next day.“We stayed parked there for a while, and then Cher curled up on the front floor board. I pulled the seat back for her—and she covered herself with my postal sweater. She was on her left side, in a fetal position. I was looking in my checkbook ’cause I had to buy school lunch tickets that next week.”Diane has just about filled in the missing time. But was it believable? Why would she stop along a lonely road, in the dark after 10:00 P.M., to balance a checkbook when they were only fifteen or twenty minutes from home? This testimony was the first time she had ever mentioned the checkbook.Jagger asked her when she remembered it.“I always remembered—but the detectives didn’t ask specific questions.”After she had put her checkbook away, she had steered the red car back down Marcola toward Springfield. She turned off onto Old Mohawk, a soft right turn. There was a house on the right.“I saw a man in the middle of my lane, flagging me down with his left hand … my thought was ‘He’s a leftie—and he’s in trouble … No—he’s got too much energy to be in trouble.’ I stopped rather quickly. None of the kids woke up. I looked to see. I took the keys with me—a standard safety precaution.”“How did you feel about the police who doubted you?”“It made me angry. It made me feel a disbelief in myself. Do I remember what I think I remember?”But Polly Jamison had helped her to feel secure with her own memory.“I felt like I was going crazy back then. I really didn’t know what was real and what wasn’t real.”Diane began revising her original story because of the dreams she was having. It was easier for her to believe that there had been two men, rather than just one, because it helped her convince herself that there had been nothing at all she could have done to save her children.“How do you feel about going through the facts now?”“I feel emotion—but not as strong. I’m scared. It was an ugly night—a crazy night. I still can’t remember everything.”Jim Jagger stopped his client repeatedly when she became defensive. He gave her a chance to expound on her feelings and memories, allowing her to let logic dictate some of the sequences of that “crazy night.”“My own memory messed me up good,” she said feelingly.Diane took a deep breath and continued more calmly. “I stopped the car. I looked around to see if the children were still asleep or awake. I opened the door, got out. He was standing at the point of the car door. He made a comment about wanting my car.“I said, ‘You’ve gotta be kidding.’”Jagger cautioned her, “Don’t fill in, Diane.”“He shoved me back toward the back of the car—a few feet. I didn’t fall. I had to catch myself. He moved toward the car. I looked in the window—and Christie was shot. It was almost simultaneous.”“You’re not crying,” Jagger offered quietly.“No.”“Why?”“There’s nothing I can do about it now.”* * *Diane’s attorney finally came to the end of his direct examination. Jim Jagger asked Diane, “You didn’t shoot your kids, and you didn’t cause anyone else to shoot your kids, did you?”“No, I did not.”* * *Fred Hugi rose slowly and walked toward Diane. It had been one year and twelve days since their brief meeting in the corridor outside the Intensive Care Unit of McKenzie-Willamette, that moment when she assured him that no one would beat her.The time had come for cross-examination.Hugi was ready. He had thought about this confrontation a thousand times, ten thousand times—at night, driving and during the lunch breaks while he sat alone in the little park across from the courthouse sipping a milkshake.Adrenalin heightened Hugi’s senses and blocked out the pain in his tooth. At last, Diane sat there on the witness stand. It was his turn.He expected no major revelation. “We knew Diane was not going to confess on the stand. The goal of cross-examination was to try to let the jury see her under some stress—to see her convoluted reasoning, inconsistencies, and the improbability of her story … to show the development of her antisocial personality.”It was going to require infinite patience, and Hugi knew he risked alienating the jury. Jagger had done that when he pushed too far with Christie. Christie was handicapped by her age and disability. Diane was hugely pregnant and appeared fragile, not at all like the sun tanned hardy woman she had been a year earlier.But her eyes were the same.Fred Hugi had a narrow path to walk.At all cost, he had vowed to appear courteous and reasonable. He would not respond with hostility unless Diane deliberately provoked him. His goals were modest. He wanted only to expose what lingered beneath Diane’s façade. He was quite willing to settle for a “few small victories and not get carried away with myself. After all this isn’t a high school debate.”Diane waited for him now on the stand, full-blown with child, faint pastel circles beneath her huge eyes. It was apparent that she held Fred Hugi in low esteem.Occasionally, as Hugi questioned Diane, he glanced toward the gallery, but his eyes never really focused on anyone. All his energy was directed toward Diane. He respected the mind behind the mask. In no way did he underestimate her.Fred Hugi too began far back in Diane’s life. The mosaic was about to be rearranged once more, flooded with a different light. He spoke to her as gently as if she were a child, his voice kind and interested.And still Jagger objected. He wanted Hugi to sit down while he questioned Diane.Fortunately, Foote overruled him. Hugi had stood to question witnesses for entire trials and was more comfortable thinking on his feet.“Let’s go back to your childhood. Was it happy? Was it sad?”“Sad … lonely.”“Why was that?”“Because my father was quite strict—intimidating—and my mother remained in the background.”“You tried to interact?”“No.”“You tried to please?”“Of course.”“How?”“I was obedient.”“You were a good student?”“I got good grades … I hated lecturing by my father.”“You were frustrated at home?”“Yes.”“Angry?”“No.” There. She stopped him. She smiled. She wasn’t angry, and he couldn’t make her say it.Unfazed, Hugi asked about the incestuous incidents between Diane and her father. “Could you be specific?”“I’d prefer not to … it continued for approximately a year.”He asked her to explain.She sighed. “Specifically?”“Yes.”“Talking, touching, being told not to tell anyone—at my father’s hand, in my house, in different rooms. The others were sleeping. My mother was working. In the car … there was fondling, touching of my chest—I had no breasts then—and other parts of my body where little kids aren’t to be touched. I blanked it out …”Her life was so sad, her problems as a child seemingly so overwhelming, and Hugi’s voice so soft that it was easy to forget that this was the prosecutor, not the defense attorney.Yet, if one listened very carefully, certain words and attitudes were being elicited from the defendant. She talked often of being trapped, of being depressed, suicidal, reclusive and rejected. Fred Hugi was showing the jury a woman who had spent years absorbing the motivation to murder, a sponge storing up rage.Diane was obviously intelligent, but she had blind sides. She could not see where Hugi was going.Her married life certainly sounded like hell. “I couldn’t make it on my own, and I wanted children. It was a case of either staying with my parents and scratching my face or going off with ‘Evil Steve.’”“Your whole life has been stressful?” Hugi asked quietly.“Not all,” she blurted cheerfully. “We haven’t even gotten to the good part yet!”Hugi read from the Washington Post and from Diane’s essay on surrogate parenting.Suddenly, Fred Hugi had led Diane into more dangerous waters, and she had waded right in, too busy talking to notice.How was it that she had had found a suitable sperm donor to conceive Danny? She explained that she really “liked” Russ.“But I set it up so he wouldn’t know about the pregnancy. I got pregnant for me—and my kids. I didn’t have many feelings about how a prospective father would feel.”Hugi’s tone had the thinnest veneer of sarcasm when he asked, “Your whole goal then was to ‘interact’ with these children?”“I still wish that I could someday get married and have a husband who would interact with his child.”“Were you getting what you needed from your children?” Hugi asked rhetorically.Apparently not. There were men in her life. She was quite willing to talk about past lovers. She divorced Steve, worked full-time at the Chandler Post Office, and met Mack Richmond.“You flirted with him?”“I flirt with everybody.”“Were there temper tantrums?” [On Diane’s part.]“Very much so!”“What brought that on?”“Mack and his wife. I couldn’t stand the way they treated their kids.”Suddenly, Diane lifted her head. She had picked up on a change in the wind, aware at long last that Fred Hugi was not as innocuous as she thought, but she relaxed again. She found him hostile but a bumbler who missed the points she was trying to make. Diane was condescending with Fred Hugi. If he wanted to talk about her lovers, it was fine with her. She had definite opinions on sex, about the fine points that differentiate dating, friendship, and sex. She “loved them all” though.To expedite matters, she offered to list all of her lovers, the circumstances of their meeting, and the details of the affairs. The press row waited, pencils poised.Hugi demurred.Diane still managed to slip most of the names in as her testimony flowed. The press row kept count as the roster grew longer.“It ended up with Lew Lewiston?” Hugi pressed on.“No, I can’t say that it did.”“Any others as intense?”“How? You mean the cards and letters?”“No—the intensity of the emotion.”She laughed harshly. “Lew was the only one dumb enough to tell his wife we were having an affair!”Diane flushed frequently, the now familiar wave of red suffusing her throat, but she never stopped talking, detailing her affair with Lew, and her struggle to wrest him free of his uncooperative wife.Even after Diane had denied that Lew meant very much to her, she defined “heart love” as the only love that really mattered. Heart Love carried with it no sexual connotations at all.That was what she had found only with Lew, she told Hugi.Diane was amused remembering aloud how she had been kicked out of Bible school for promiscuity. She was sad because she had always been lonely. The heller vixen and the lonely child fought each other for a spot in the witness chair.Guns and houses and men and relationships and even children had changed hands so often in Diane’s life. She had not been able to hold on to anything.Jim Jagger appeared serene at the defense table. He cannot shut his client up. There seemed no point in objecting. Diane was doing damage to herself, as Hugi had hoped she would. He had opened the floodgates. He had only to stand aside, and let her talk. Jagger would have another chance on re-direct. Possibly he could patch the worst damage then.* * *During recesses, Ray Broderick sat on one of the long benches outside the courtroom, doodling his endless cartoons on the small pad he always carried. His humor was sometimes macabre and usually pun oriented. Today, he drew an awe-struck crowd gazing up as a woman floats down in a billowing greatcoat and bonnet, clinging to her umbrella. And the crowd shouts in horror, “Wait—it’s not Mary Poppins! It’s Diane Downs!”Cartoons, only some of them from Broderick’s hand, had surfaced from time to time. At the CSD office, someone had tacked up a mimeographed copy of a cartoon drawn by an anonymous artist. It portrayed a very pregnant Diane Downs attempting to escape from jail. She holds a pistol to her belly, warning, “Stop or I’ll shoot!”* * *But, still, Diane had her champions. There were regulars in the gallery who could not make up their minds and who could well reflect the jurors’ feelings. A sweet faced woman with tears in her eyes talked to a reporter: “It’s confusing. Sometimes I think she’s guilty, and sometimes I just feel like going up and giving her a hug.”There was a tall quiet man who said nothing more than that he believed Diane’s testimony.Wednesday morning was even warmer. It really felt like spring. Diane was wearing the royal blue dress with the pattern of gulls flying. It was her prettiest maternity outfit and looked expensive. She finally was forced to repeat some of her outfits as the trial stretched out.Diane had had all night to mull over her responses to Fred Hugi’s cross-examination. Jagger had pointed out to her that Hugi had deliberately let her rattle on. She was not such an unknowing adversary this morning. She watched Hugi warily as he approached the witness stand.Hugi began not with the night of the shooting, but back with the incident in the Arizona desert, as if he were reading a book, had put it down for a spell, and must reread a few chapters to remind himself of the story. The jury had heard so much in the past three days that they needed this recap.Diane acknowledged her terror as she drove with her father into the desert. That was the very last time Wes had touched her. She recalled that she screamed, “You’re killing me!”Diane explained to Fred Hugi that even when she’s “crazy,” she’s “rational”—that she promotes herself as more rational than she is, so that she will appear strong.“That’s not telling the truth then?” Hugi prodded.“Okay.”“Were you angry at your mother?”“No.”“… for not protecting you?”“Not really. She was just as trapped as I was. She wouldn’t have believed me. I was just a little kid, and he was a grown-up man.”“You believe people should believe a grown-up over a child?”“Not necessarily.”Damn! He had zapped her again.Hugi held Diane’s essay on child abuse in his hand. As he began to question her about it, she offered to read it aloud. She was very proud of it, totally unaware of the damage it could do here. Hugi handed it to her. Diane had just offered the prosecution a coup.She read well, her voice strong as she cautioned parents and grandparents that if they abuse their helpless children, the vicious circle will continue endlessly, twisting in upon itself and harming children yet unborn.As Diane finished, the courtroom was hushed.“… Remember the cycle—generation unto generation.”She turned to Hugi, a genius deigning to engage in conversation with a dolt.“Do you understand it, Mr. Hugi? If you can stop the cycle—I stopped.”“Is that how you stopped the abuse—by eliminating an entire generation?” Hugi asked bluntly.“No, Mr. Hugi, I did not … I have never sexually abused my children. If you stop the cycle, you stop the abuse.” She snapped at him, annoyed. “Mr. Hugi, you irritate me! You’re not listening. You’re not listening—”But of course, he was. Fred Hugi was listening to every word the defendant said, to every inflection. He cared not the least that Diane lectured him.Diane had also written papers on peer pressure and drugs, smoking and alcohol. “I felt I was lucky—that it was beneficial that I had no friends—no bad habits.”So soon, she had forgotten the warnings to beware of the prosecutor. Diane talked almost as freely with Fred Hugi as she had with Jim Jagger. At times, when she chided him, they seemed to be the only two people in the room. From her mythical “seventh level” of intelligence she saw him far below.She was woefully mistaken.Hugi asked about her sexual problems with her husband. Had they been her father’s fault too?“No. Because it was fine before marriage. After, he’d come home at 3:00 A.M. from being out with friends and expected me to please him.”And then, they spoke of the unicorn. “I saw it in the window for a week in Cottage Grove, and I thought that Cheryl would really like it—but no favorites. I thought ‘Hey, this is our new start on life—something eternal.’ It was wild and free—a unicorn is a type of horse, and a horse is wild and free—”“Have you ever studied what a unicorn means?”“No,” Diane answered. “I heard from a detective that it was ‘magical.’”“Things did change drastically in Oregon?” Hugi asked.“Yes.”“He [Lew] wouldn’t accept letters, cards—?“… after a point.”“How long?”“One and a half to two weeks after I got here … I was hurt … I wasn’t devastated, ’cause I already had a male companion. Mr. Samuelson was a better substitute than Lew. Mr. Samuelson paid his own way!”Substitute for what?No, Diane replied, she did not confide to friends that Mr. Samuelson was not as good in bed as Lew. Yes, she had lied to Lew about not having other men, “’cause men don’t want to believe you’re fooling around.”She would not admit that she longed desperately for Lew Lewiston. “He told me to write him every day. I really expected him … I took a lot of time to make him feel loved and secure. He was never the only one. To an extent—I made a commitment to Lew—but he wasn’t my whole life. I even dated people you aren’t aware of …”What was Diane trying to do? It made sense for her to make Lew Lewiston sound negligible, and hardly all-consuming. But why was she so eager to present herself as a trollop, greedy for sex, with lovers yet untold? Only the day before, Diane had been too shy to tell the jury that her ex-husband had done something sexually disgusting to her while she lay unconscious from alcohol and, perhaps, drugs.Was it about “power” again? Was she ashamed of it because Steve had forced himself on her, and sex was only permissible when she was the one who chose it? Or was she still trying to convince herself, and everyone listening, that she was no longer the ugly duckling, that she was pretty enough for men to want her?Fred Hugi asked Diane about the letter diary. Why had she written all those longing letters but not sent them?“If I kept these letters of undying love, I could show them to Lew when he showed up here. I knew he would show up here one day, and I’d show him the letters.”It would be Diane’s way to show Lew how much she’d missed him.“They were lies then?” Hugi’s questions were short, like quick jabs to the gut, and just as effective.“They were ‘untruths.’ ‘Lie’ is a strong word—like ‘hate.’ Like saying ‘hate’ for ‘dislike.’ The fact is I do love him, and I was also relaying my love for him. I simply overdramatized what was the truth.”“You’ve done that before,” Hugi said quickly. “You’ve never been told you were a histrionic personality?”“What?”He had her. She did not know the meaning of the word.“You never heard the results of your psychological tests?”“I’ve never heard that word.”Diane hastened to explain her diary. “If I loved him as much as I said in those letters, wouldn’t I have sent them … or a telegram he could not refuse?”“You did send them, and they were refused. You spent $200 for one day in Arizona to see Lew—”“To return his chain … to see Lew … to see Jack.”She reminded Hugi that she got a hug and a kiss from Jack Lenta, not from Lew. She couldn’t call Lew, because he and his wife had an unlisted number. She couldn’t call Jack that night, because he was married, so she’d called Steve. She’d purchased a bottle of Jim Beam on the way from the airport. Her memory had cleared. She now recalled intercourse in the living room of Steve’s place and that she was moaning and calling Lew’s name during the sex act. Her moaning had awakened Steve’s roommate.“Was this a rape—or some sort of sex crime?” Hugi asks.“Yeah—that’s a good way to put it.”“You got up in the morning, and had Steve drive you to the post office?”“Yeah.”“You didn’t report it?”“Ha! I’m often the victim of a crime with Steve—” She sighed at her interrogator’s reasoning. “Mr. Hugi, you can believe what you want. I know what happened. Steve knows what happened.”Diane’s tone grew more sarcastic with each question. Fred Hugi was another man trying to exert his power over her. Beating him had become more important than convincing the jury.She has forgotten the jury.“Do you know the words to Duran Duran’s ‘Hungry Like the Wolf?’”“No. Usually not. With New Wave music, you listen to the music.”“They all have the same theme?”“I don’t know.”“Your activities with the children really started in the first week in May, didn’t they?”“No—since April 4th.”“They didn’t surface in the letters [to Lew].”“Only because the letters were to Lew—for Lew. The kids surfaced because they were becoming more important to me than Lew. I was losing interest in Lew. I was running out of things to say to Lew. How many things can you say to patronize someone?”Fred Hugi read to her from the letter diary.“It was a lot of mush,” Diane insisted. “Something you write to a man. If I felt that mushy all the time, I wouldn’t be able to deliver my mail straight.”Undaunted, Hugi read more of the purple prose aloud.Diane responded, her attitude rude and insolent as she explained that Lew’s doubts about kids hadn’t been the only problem. Until now, she hadn’t bothered to mention Lew’s other excuses. She ticked them off on her long fingers. “Nora’s scoliosis … Nora’s folks’ money … his guilt about leaving Nora after four years.“Mr. Hugi, all of my boyfriends are married. How can you say I couldn’t be comfortable with a man that loves another woman?”The press row glanced at the female jurors, all married.Diane seemed bored as Hugi read from the psychiatric evaluation done in Kentucky, the reports that indicated major psychopathology, anxiety, and depression. She dismissed them with a wave of her hand. “Those tests were done in 1981. They were Steve’s fault … It’s true [the test results]. I faced the problems. I got a divorce—and then I got pregnant with a surrogate baby.”* * *It had grown hot in the courtroom. It was muggy, airless and more confining than ever. The press bench was one solid gel of bodies, with seemingly disembodied hands struggling to take notes at a hundred miles an hour. The press had never heard a murder defendant reveal herself so nakedly on the witness stand.A battle of titans continued, a dialogue between masters of debate—one trained, the other instinctual.Fred Hugi suggested to Diane that she must have felt desperate when she found herself in Oregon without Lew. Trapped again.“Circumstances can’t trap you—people trap you.”Hugi peppered her with rapid fire questions about the night of May 19.“You went to see Heather? Why?”To take the clipping, of course—about the free horses.“Was it dark?”“No, Mr. Hugi—it was light.”“Were your headlights on?”“No.”“When you left, were they on?”“Yes.”“You couldn’t have just called her—to tell her about the free horses?”“She didn’t have a phone.”“So you leave—and it’s dark?”“Yes.”“At Marcola Road, you go sightseeing in the dark?”“Yes.”“Where?”“The Deerhorn—”She talked with Cheryl. She pulled off to the side of the road to work on her checkbook.“You decided—”“I didn’t decide. I just did.”“How much time passes when you’re pulled over?”“How should I know?”“Is this a dream or did it happen?” Hugi could match her sarcasm when he wanted to.“It happened.”“How long?”“I can’t tell you because you’ll make a fact of it.”“A half hour?”“NO!”“A minute?”“It was more than a minute.”Again, she went over her little conversation with Cheryl as they were parked on the side of Marcola Road, while she balanced her checkbook. Diane remembered that they talked about Cheryl’s new kitten too.“Okay. You’re not sightseeing when you leave there. You’re going back to town?”“Yes.”“Was the tape playing?”“Probably. It was always playing.”“How were you feeling?”“Fine.”“Not depressed?”“Why would I be depressed?”“You decide to turn on Old Mohawk—a secluded road?”“Yes. The road didn’t look secluded to me.”“You saw a man in the road?”“Yes.”“You had your three children with you. It was dark enough to have your headlights on. Yet, you decided to stop the car. Why is that?”Diane shook her head wearily and rolled her eyes. This was all so ridiculous. Patiently, bored, she explained it to him again. If someone was hurt she didn’t want anyone to pick up the injured party and injure him further. So she couldn’t just roll down the window. She’d taken the keys for the children’s safety. What if Cheryl had tried to climb up on the seat and hit the gear shift?He wanted more details, and she sighed with exasperation.“My goodness, Mr. Hugi! That was a year ago!”“Not a very significant event in your life?”“Not before—Why hadn’t she pushed the bush haired stranger away?Because she’d been caught off guard. “I’ve had no reason to doubt anyone.”Diane’s description of her entire life had been one long saga of rejection and betrayal, but now she said she had never had reason to doubt anyone.She’d seen Christie shot, because the dome light was on. What details might she remember, even after a whole year?“… the eye contact and the bullet holes …”“You slammed the door on him?”“No, Mr. Hugi. I did not.”Diane’s yellow eyes were blazing. She was enraged with Fred Hugi. How dare he insinuate that she didn’t really try to save her children? He was just like Doug Welch and Kurt Wuest in that taped interview. Her hatred for Hugi was palpable.“Go ahead,” she hissed. “Ask me another question.”“And then, he—”“He asked for the car again.”Unbelieving, Hugi asked, “A car with three gunshot kids in it?”“Who can make sense out of an insane man?”“Person—”“Man—”“Person—”“Man.”* * *Tell it again, Diane. The stranger hit her hand with his gun. She deflected the gun. He demanded the car again, and she faked throwing the keys over her left shoulder with her right hand. He looked in that direction. She pushed him. She leapt into the car and left.She recalled that her arm was shot when he was three or four feet away, but she somehow managed to get the key in the ignition and drive off before he could reach her.“You never saw him again?”“No, thank you. I have not.”“You drove fast?”“I don’t know, Mr. Hugi.”“Fast enough—as you said—for the car door to slam shut?”“I guess—”Countless times, she had told the story of her frantic drive to the hospital and now she recited it again by rote. She was the injured mother, trying to comfort her dying children as she raced to save their lives.“At the stop light, I saw the towel around my arm—”“You took care of yourself,” Hugi cut in.“I did everything for those kids to try to save them! If I passed out, they wouldn’t have a chance.”She could not recall any car behind her or any lights in the windows of the dozens of houses she’d passed. She’d seen only a white fence. She had thought only of getting to the hospital.She had known immediately that she had some blank spots, but the detectives had pushed her to come up with something. “I think the detectives were unfair because they wouldn’t accept what I didn’t know.”Hugi reminded Diane that none of the hospital personnel had seen her shed a tear.“Isn’t that funny? I only saw the doctors ten minutes that night, and the nurses fifteen. I don’t imagine they saw much of anything.”“You feel the hospital was responsible for the children [Cheryl] dying?”“I only found out here how Cheryl died. She died almost instantly. She had clots in her throat. When they cleaned that out, all the blood came up from her lungs. She had heart wounds, spleen. There was no blood on the car carpet.”Diane was near tears now, but the tears were of rage and frustration.* * *After lunch, the courtroom was packed even tighter than it had been during the morning session. Diane resumed the witness stand, her now flat eyes fixed on the prosecutor.“You ever suffer head injuries?” Fred Hugi began. The State’s psychiatrist, Dr. George Suckow, needed this information so that he could validate, or dismiss, the possibility that Diane suffered from amnesia, repression, memory loss, and/or unconscious transference when Hugi called him as a rebuttal witness.“Yes. When Steve and I were married. In the living room—in 1975.”“This night?” Hugi asked, referring to May 19, 1983.“Nope.”“Ever wake up in a different place and not know how you got there?”“Nope.”“… but you had memory problems from the time of the shooting until you got to the hospital?”“No.”“Your memory bad in the hospital—?”“Yes.”“When does it get better?”“The next morning when I woke up—I still had gaps and holes in my memory.”No, she did not remember that she described the suspect differently to Dick Tracy and to Rob Charboneau.Hugi pounded her with questions. How could the shooter know the children were there inside the car? Was he walking into the headlights? Could he see?“I wasn’t inside his head.”She could not remember where the shooter stood—inside— outside—his arm through a window…“Mr. Hugi, your people wanted everything to be exact.”“You were being pressured?”“Yes.”“You faked throwing the keys—and then you said you lied. Which is true?”“What I just said. I faked—”“Why?”“People were hassling me. Steve and others. I had a lot of self doubt—but I never doubted that I didn’t shoot my children.”She had forgotten the trees, the white lines and the road itself, but inside her own body, she had thought she was going fast. Yes, she’d told the detectives she’d never fired a handgun, never owned one and never “possessed” one. “That’s true—they were Steve’s.”“… never possessed?”“True.”“Never possessed?”Diane called for a timeout. To her “possess” meant to own. She did not want to talk about the .22 Ruger.“It was Steve’s gun. It was in my house.”Her arm had pained her terribly and acted “kooky, real weird.” She had heard that the detectives considered her injury a flesh wound. She shrugged her martyr’s shrug.“‘I don’t know who shot my kids’ you said,” Hugi said. “‘I haven’t the vaguest idea’?”“True.”“‘I do know,’ you said.”“True.”“The suspect ‘held my arm and called me a bitch?’”“True.”“You said the yellow car tied in?”“True.”“How does it tie in?”“I don’t know … everyone told me nothing made sense, your people, Steve, Lew. Even my dreams didn’t make sense.”“Your parents told you that too?”“Not my parents.”“You said, ‘they’ touched you—threatened to pluck your tattoo?”“I said that.”“Why?”“I believed it until I got some help.”“When did you decide to get help?”“I didn’t. My attorney did, ’cause I was on the verge of suicide. You listened to the tapes—they’re idiotic. That woman was in trouble. Why didn’t you get me help?”“If you shot your own kids, would you have gone crazy?”“I wouldn’t do it, Mr. Hugi.”“Ever threaten Steve?”“That depends on what you mean.”“His life?”“No.”“Point a gun at him?”“No—I’m the type of person that would cut off my nose to spite my face. I say lots of things to impress people that should never be said. That don’t mean anything. I make my flip remarks … If I kept my mouth shut, a lot of times, I’d save people a lot of trouble, including myself.”Over objections, Fred Hugi pointed out that Polly Jamison’s tests revealed that Diane was a deviant sociopath. Diane appeared puzzled. It was another term she did not understand.“You told Detective Norenberg [a handwriting expert] that a trial is a play and that the best actors will win,” Hugi reminded her. “You thought I would cut you off and not let you explain your answers?”“Yes.”“Have I cut you off?”“No. I appreciate that. Thank you.”Fred Hugi turns to Jim Jagger: “Your witness.”* * *“When you said that you didn’t care if they caught anyone,” Jagger began on re-direct, “that you wanted it dropped, I called the sheriff’s office and told them I was getting you to a psychologist?”She nodded indulgently. “Don’t I always [say the wrong thing]?”Hadn’t Jagger always urged her to be honest with him from the beginning? Guilty or innocent? Hadn’t he urged her not to talk so freely? Hadn’t he said, “Do what you feel is right. We’ll fly by the truth. Even if you’re inconsistent, we’ll deal with it later?”Of course. She nodded with a smile.Jagger had more inconsistencies to deal with in Diane’s myriad versions of the shootings than any lawyer might wish for in three trials. He stressed Diane’s Baptist upbringing and the Good Samaritan angle. Given her religious training, she had no alternative but to stop for the stranger.Jagger tried to erase the picture of the promiscuous woman who preferred married men. He asked Diane to tell about the many men she had dated with whom she had had no physical intimacy.There was Scott, and Ray, who “certified your dog bites, and Rick who wanted to adopt her children, and Tim who played softball and video games with the kids. But then Lew had come along and he had “higher priority.”“Did you have priorities more important than men?” Jagger asked.“My business, flying, and my kids.”Fred Hugi objected to the admission of Diane’s second diary, the post shooting diary. “The diary is totally self-serving … it’s Diane Downs’s world as she would like it to be.”At length, Judge Foote sustained Hugi’s objections. Diane could refer to the diary to refresh her memory in court, but it would not be admitted.* * *Fred Hugi had a few more questions.Diane assured him she had not been abusive to her kids for at least two years. Not since her divorce. “My life goes on spans—milestones.”“Did your plan to move to Oregon include Lew?”“Initially, no …”“You expected him to join you here?”“Yes.”Diane scolded Hugi. “Christie’s been in a lot of trouble, and you people are forgetting that. She’s taking over a lot of Cheryl’s personality, and that scares me really bad. She also woke up crying about wetting the bed, and she’s never wet the bed—”“You never recall grabbing Christie by the throat either?” Hugi spat.“NO!” Diane’s throat blossomed pink.Hugi walked away. He was done with her.CHAPTER 42“I told my wife, ‘Look at that ugly creep!’ Well, my wife drives down the road—all she sees is the white line … He was on drugs, I figured … His eyes were so big. I seen lots of ’em at Sisters—or right here on the Mall …”—Jim-Bob McCoin, Witness for the DefenseThe bulk of the defense’s case rested on Diane’s shoulders. In four and a half days on the stand, she had given testimony far beyond the scope of questioning by her own attorney and Fred Hugi.The gallery waited expectantly for more, but Jagger had no big guns waiting in the wings for the defense. There would be no surprise witnesses.There was John Hulce, the elderly gentleman who spotted an old yellow car days after the shooting, and Basil Wilson, who saw a tramp with the green and blue bag in the country club. Wilson wore a white cashmere sweater with the country club emblem over his heart as he explained that “all hippies look alike” so he could not really describe the bum with the bicycle who had the audacity to wander into a private club.The defense deserved points for variety. Jagger next called two witnesses who described themselves as “chicken farmers.” Jim-Bob McCoin and Norm Hilliard, had contacted Jagger some weeks after the shooting. He referred them to Roy Pond, who found that they shared an address on the same street, but six blocks away from, the Wes and Willadene Frederickson residence in Springfield.It was late in the day when their names were called, and they had apparently imbibed freely to brace themselves for the ordeal of testifying. Alcoholic fumes wafted through the courtroom as each made his way to the stand. Hilliard and McCoin had visited Marcola Road that May night, although they had never crossed the threshold of the Springfield Country Club, and had no desire to. Norman Preston Hilliard, thirty, and his good friend, Jim-Bob McCoin, were, as they phrased it, taking care of some “game chickens” out at a friend’s house between the golf course and the Mohawk Store.Since cock fighting is illegal in Oregon, it was prudent for Norm and Jim-Bob to downplay their errand that evening. A two car caravan had left the chicken coops for Springfield about a quarter past nine. Andy Waldron, a friend, had driven Hilliard. Jim-Bob and his wife had followed in their own vehicle.Hilliard recalled, “We was due for dinner at Jim-Bob’s mother’s house at 9:30, and we got there at 9:25.”As they approached the bridge over the Mohawk River (just at the intersection of Marcola and Sunderman roads) Hilliard had seen a man near the bridge, hitchhiking. He recalled that he had a steady look at him. The man was wearing an army fatigue jacket and blue jeans, and was carrying a “sky blue” bag. His round face was unshaven, and he had “deep, deep, dark eyes.” The man’s hair had been medium brown with bangs combed down, cut below his ears and above his shoulders—“shaggy, windblown”—five feet, ten inches, and about one hundred ninety-five pounds.“We was going about forty to forty-five miles an hour. I heard about the shooting the next morning and didn’t give it no thought until I saw the second composite. I compared it to my wife and children—if that happened to them—and I called her lawyer.”Hilliard had difficulty remembering his contact with Detective Pond. “Something I’ll need to remember in my life, I’ll keep notes. I never thought it would come to this that a man has to remember every minute to be that perzact!”Jim-Bob McCoin figured he saw the man at the bridge “between 9:20 and 9:25—I never pack a watch—I break ’em.” The man had been on the north side of the road, headed toward Springfield. He had hair a little past his ears, looked like he hadn’t shaved in six weeks, and wore a green army fatigue jacket and blue jeans. Jim-Bob remembered the stranger as fat and chunky, under five feet eight.”The witness jerked his thumb at Judge Foote, drawing guffaws, as he suggested that the stranger looked something like “this guy here.” Courtroom protocol was foreign to McCoin. He apparently did not know that Foote was the judge. Since Foote stood well over six feet and was no way “fat and chunky,” it was a flawed comparison.Neither had seen “no yellow car.”Their descriptions of the man didn’t quite mesh, but both said he had worn an army fatigue jacket. Diane had described a man in a Levi jacket. The stranger they had seen on the bridge was walking toward Springfield. It was conceivable that he might have veered off to the right when he came to the Mohawk Road.This was the sort of suspect that Wes had looked for so assiduously—a wild drug mad tramp seen out in the country only a half hour before his family was shot. No one had seen the man since. If he was the same man Basil Wilson had seen earlier, he had gained weight and lost his bicycle …Why on earth would Diane Downs, with her three little children in the car, have stopped for such a wild looking stranger? Even as a Good Samaritan?As McCoin left the stand, he swaggered out of the courtroom and hit both doors as if he were leaving an old-time western saloon. Only one door opened, and he spun out of control, around the post holding the cordon that kept the crowd back. There was a crash in the hall.Someone giggled and Judge Foote rapped for order.* * *“Call Willadene Frederickson!”Diffidently, Willadene approached to be sworn. She looked very nice, like a matron dressed up in her navy blue suit with a red and white striped tie for a spring Sunday at church.Diane turned in her chair and smiled—a little wistful smile. She looked for the moment like a child whose mommy had shown up in the nick of time to save her. She had so often scorned Willadene as wishy-washy, but her mother was there.Her father was not.Willadene smiled back at Diane, placing her hand on the Bible. Willadene recalled to Jim Jagger that Diane had arrived in Springfield on Easter Sunday in 1983. “We left Oregon for Arizona ten days before. We had a pickup, and Diane had two cars. Katherine drove the white Ford Fiesta back.”Willadene had seen a microwave and a small television in the trunk of Diane’s Nissan. She saw a rifle case on a little ledge at the back of the trunk, and a “cloth item. I moved it. It felt like a gun—”Willadene had seen only a portion of the gun. She sighed as she attempted to draw it on the blackboard. “I don’t know a thing about guns, but I saw a cylinder, and it wasn’t flat.”Willadene wiped tears from her eyes as she recalled the night of May 19, 1983. She described her daughter as “hysterical—crying when I got there. Her eyes were red, her face was red, and tears were running down her face.”Now, Willadene sobbed as she remembered her lost grandchildren and struggled to regain her composure.Jim Jagger questioned her about her family and how they were during the growing up years. “Who was the enforcer of rules when you were raising kids?”“I’d say pretty much both—he was head of the household.”What had they told their children about crying?“We taught them not to be crybabies—to knock it off.
